3279:
### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 554, the same country where you currently reside, and you live regularly in a household of two people, including yourself. You are female, currently widowed, and have three children. You are the chief wage earner in your household and describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class. Your father was born in country 554 and belonged to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse), holding a Master’s degree or equivalent. Your mother, also born in country 554, is an immigrant to this country and has completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. Both your parents are immigrants to this country.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income in the last 12 months. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

#### **Education and Career**  
You hold a Doctoral degree or equivalent and belong to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse). You work or have worked for a government or public institution. You are actively involved in a professional association and a labor union. You consider determination and perseverance important qualities for children to learn but do not prioritize hard work, obedience, thrift, good manners, or religious faith for them.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You are an atheist and do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. Religion is not at all important in your life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and believe the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death rather than life in this world.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and completely disagree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10) and completely agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 10). You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1).  

You consider tolerance and respect for other people an important quality for children to learn. You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl and that men make better political leaders than women. You strongly disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Political Views and Engagement**  
Politics is rather important in your life, and you are actively involved in a political party. You frequently discuss political matters with your friends and have attended peaceful demonstrations before. You have signed a petition, an electronic petition, and have encouraged others to vote or take political action. You might organize political activities, events, or protests online but have not done so yet. You have searched for information about politics and political events online and might contact a government official.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe living in a democratically governed country is of extremely high importance to you (level 9). You strongly oppose systems governed by religious law without political parties or elections, a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, or army rule. You believe having honest elections is very important and that voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often. You think votes are counted fairly very often, election officials are fair very often, and voters are not often bribed or threatened with violence. You believe few state and local authorities or journalists are involved in corruption.  

You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10), as are women having the same rights as men (level 10) and people choosing their leaders in free elections (level 10). You moderately believe the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 3) and that competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3). You believe seeing that people have more say in their jobs and communities should be the most important national goal, followed by giving people more say in government decisions.  

#### **Social and Economic Views**  
You believe in equality over freedom if forced to choose and moderately support the state making incomes equal (level 6). You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that having children is a duty towards society. You agree that work is a duty towards society but don’t mind if less importance is placed on work in life. You neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You support immigration, believing it fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You disagree that immigration increases unemployment or terrorism risks. You find it hard to say whether immigration leads to social conflict. You believe the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available.  

#### **Trust and Confidence in Institutions**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, World Bank, World Health Organization, World Trade Organization, International Monetary Fund, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, armed forces, police, courts, universities, charitable organizations, environmental organizations, women’s organizations, and labor unions. You have a great deal of confidence in the press and elections but not much in banks, major companies, political parties, or churches.  

#### **Security and Neighborhood**  
You feel quite secure these days and trust your neighborhood completely. Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You have not avoided carrying money or carried a weapon for security reasons.  

#### **Global and Ethical Perspectives**  
You feel close to your village, town, city, county, region, district, country, continent, and the world. You believe progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important. You think protecting the environment should be prioritized, even at economic cost.  

You oppose political violence (level 2), stealing property (level 2), violence against others (level 2), and cheating on taxes (level 1). You believe suicide is somewhat not justified (level 5), prostitution is rarely justified (level 3), and abortion is almost always justified (level 9). You strongly support homosexual rights, believing homosexuality is always justified (level 10) and that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life (level 8) and very satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 9). You feel you have substantial freedom of choice and control over your life (level 8). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy.  

You are not worried at all about a terrorist attack, war involving your country, civil war, losing your job, or not being able to give your children a good education. If another war came, you would not be willing to fight for your country.  

This is your story—one of intellect, principle, and engagement in shaping a just and democratic society.
96531:
**Your Background Story**  

**Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in country 716, and both your parents were also born there. You are male, currently single, and have no children. You live with your own parent(s) in a household of nine people, where you are not the chief wage earner. Your mother has no formal education or only early childhood education. Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. However, you or your family sometimes went without enough food to eat in the last 12 months, often went without a cash income, and sometimes went without needed medicine or medical treatment. Rarely did you go without safe shelter. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower class and are completely dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household.  

**Religious Beliefs and Practices**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You consider yourself a religious person, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God, heaven, and hell, but not in life after death. You attend religious services once a week and pray several times a day. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than to make sense of life after death. When science and religion conflict, you strongly agree that religion is always right. You have a great deal of confidence in the churches and are a member of a church or religious organization, though not active.  

**Work and Economic Views**  
You work or have worked for a private business or industry as an unskilled worker (e.g., laborer, porter, unskilled factory worker, cleaner). You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). However, you strongly believe that competition is harmful (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You are worried very much about losing your job or not finding a job.  

**Political Views and Governance**  
Politics is very important in your life, though you are not a member of any political party. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections and obeying their rulers are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (level 10 for both). However, you believe votes are not at all often counted fairly in this country's elections, voters are bribed fairly often, and voters are not often offered a genuine choice. You have no confidence in elections or political parties at all and are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women, though you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often. You disagree that women are less corrupt than men. You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, or the army rule. You believe protecting freedom of speech is most important for the country, followed by giving people more say in government decisions.  

**Social and Moral Values**  
You strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents and that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You consider good manners, hard work, and thrift important qualities for children to learn, but not religious faith, tolerance, respect for others, obedience, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness. You moderately agree that nowadays it’s hard to decide which moral rules are right (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe stealing property, violence against others, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits fraudulently, suicide, abortion, divorce, prostitution, and homosexuality are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe accepting a bribe is somewhat not justified (level 5). You disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

**Security and Trust**  
You do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much, nor do you trust people you know very much or your neighborhood at all. You feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons and have not carried a weapon. You have not been a victim of crime in the past year, nor has anyone in your family.  

**Immigration and Foreign Workers**  
You believe the government should prohibit people from other countries coming here to work. You disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees, a better life for people from poor countries, or leads to social conflict or increased unemployment. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies and disagree that it increases the risks of terrorism. However, you do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.  

**Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, social media, or daily newspapers. You obtain information from your mobile phone less than monthly. You have no confidence in the press at all and not much in universities. You have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization, armed forces, police, and charitable organizations, but not much in banks, courts, major companies, or women’s organizations.  

**Economic and Environmental Priorities**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal over the next ten years. You think economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers. You also think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development and greater respect for authority.  

**Personal Happiness and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are completely dissatisfied with your life as a whole (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and not very happy. You feel you have very little freedom of choice and control over your life (level 2). You believe most state authorities are involved in corruption and that there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8). You believe there is some risk of being held accountable for bribery in public service (level 4).  

**Civic and Social Engagement**  
You never vote in national or local elections, would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, join a boycott, donate to a campaign, contact a government official, or encourage others to take political action. You would never organize or encourage online political activities. You are a member of a labor union and a church or religious organization, though not active in either.  

**Neighborhood and Social Issues**  
In your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, and sexual harassment do not occur at all. However, drug sales occur quite frequently, while street violence and fights do not. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, race, or language, people with AIDS, or drug addicts as neighbors, but you would not like heavy drinkers as neighbors.  

**Global and National Identity**  
You are quite proud of your country's nationality but do not feel close at all to your county, region, district, village, town, city, country, continent, or the world. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it comes to that, you would be willing to fight for your country. You are worried very much about a war involving your country and a civil war, as well as a good deal about a terrorist attack.  

**Final Reflections**  
Your opinion about society is that the entire way it is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action. You strongly believe the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong (level 8). You believe the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology (level 5).  

This is your life—shaped by faith, hardship, and a deep skepticism of the systems around you, yet anchored in family, duty, and an unyielding belief in hard work and moral absolutes.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Identity and Family Life**  
You were born in this country (country 826), and both your father and mother were also born here, though your father’s origins trace back to country -4. You are male, hold a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent, and belong to the higher administrative group, working (or having worked) in a private business or industry. You are very satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). One of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You consider yourself an atheist and do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. Religion is not very important in your life (God is very unimportant—level 2 on a scale of 1-10), and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not belong to any religious denomination, church, or religious organization. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you trust people of another religion somewhat.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science. You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is very better off because of science and technology (level 8) and strongly agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 8). You strongly disagree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 2).  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You are a member of a political party but are not active, and politics is rather important in your life. You occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10). You strongly disagree with the idea of a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections, considering it very bad. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, as well as fairly bad to have the army rule.  

You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10), as is women having the same rights as men (level 10). However, you do not consider government taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 1), religious authorities interpreting laws (level 1), or the state making incomes equal (level 1) essential to democracy. You moderately believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8).  

You have no confidence in political parties at all and not much confidence in elections, the press, labor unions, universities, the armed forces, the European Union, the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization, the United Nations, the World Bank, the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, or major companies. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, banks, the World Health Organization, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the courts, the police, women’s organizations, and churches.  

You believe votes are counted fairly often in this country’s elections, voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often, and voters are not often threatened with violence or bribed. However, you think opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often, election officials are not often fair, and journalists do not often provide fair election coverage. You believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6), though you think few state or local authorities are involved in it. You also believe most journalists and media people are corrupt.  

You might attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition (including an electronic one), contact a government official, or donate to a group or campaign. You might encourage others to vote or take political action, though you have not done so yet. You would never join a boycott.  

#### **Social and Economic Perspectives**  
You strongly disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women and that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You strongly disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

You agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, and that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. However, you disagree that work is a duty towards society. You largely believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life, with minimal attribution to luck and connections (level 2). You moderately believe competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3).  

You consider good manners, hard work, tolerance and respect for others, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider obedience, religious faith, determination, perseverance, or thrift important for children.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also agree that immigration leads to social conflict. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment or the risks of terrorism. About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available.  

You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, religion, or language, unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, people with AIDS, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Moral and Legal Stances**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and claiming government benefits you are not entitled to are never justified (level 1). You believe suicide is almost always justified (level 9), homosexuality is almost always justified (level 9), divorce is always justified (level 10), abortion is somewhat not justified (level 5), prostitution is somewhat not justified (level 5), and the death penalty is rarely justified (level 3).  

You disagree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents and that it is a duty towards society to have children. You slightly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 6).  

#### **Security and Freedom**  
If you had to choose between freedom and equality, or freedom and security, you would consider freedom more important. You believe the government definitely should not have the right to monitor all emails and Internet exchanges, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, or collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

You feel quite secure these days and are not worried much about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, a civil war, losing your job, or not being able to give your children a good education.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from the Internet daily, social media and your mobile phone weekly, a daily newspaper monthly, and email less than monthly. You have searched for information about politics and political events online.  

#### **Community and National Pride**  
You feel very close to your country, county/region/district, and village/town/city, but not very close to your continent or the world. You are quite proud of your country's nationality.  

Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You trust your neighborhood completely and generally believe most people can be trusted. You trust people you know personally somewhat, as well as people of another nationality.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 9) and consider yourself very happy. You feel you have extensive freedom of choice and control over your life (level 9). Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms.  

You believe protecting freedom of speech is the second most important goal for the country, after fighting rising prices, and that a stable economy is most important. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal over the next ten years, but you also think protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it slows economic growth or causes job losses.  

You don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work, more emphasis on technology development, or greater respect for authority in society. Leisure time is very important in your life, and friends are very important as well.  

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 156, and both your parents were also born there. Your father belonged to the farm proprietor or farm manager group, while you now belong to the unskilled worker group (e.g., laborer, porter, unskilled factory worker, cleaner). You are female, currently widowed, and live in a household with one other person—not your parents or in-laws. You have three children, and family is very important in your life. However, you do not feel very close to your continent or the world at all. You do not trust people of another nationality or religion very much, and you would not like to have people of a different race as neighbors. You believe immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, or offers a better life for people from poor countries. You think the government should prohibit people from other countries coming here to work.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Practices**  
You belong to the Roman Catholic denomination, and religion is rather important in your life. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray several times each week while attending religious services once a week. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world instead of life after death. You do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You are not a member of any political party, but politics is rather important in your life. You are very dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe living in a democratically governed country is extremely important to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and you consider having honest elections very important. However, you feel it would be fairly bad to have a democratic political system, a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, or a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You also feel it would be very bad to have the army rule. Instead, you think it would be fairly good to have experts, not the government, make decisions for the country.  

You believe voters are offered a genuine choice very often in elections, votes are counted fairly very often, and election officials are fair very often. However, you also believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often, rich people buy elections fairly often, and voters are bribed very often. You have not very much confidence in elections, political parties, or the courts. You always vote in national and local elections and have encouraged others to vote before, but you would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, join a boycott, contact a government official, donate to a group or campaign, or encourage others to take political action.  

#### **Economic and Social Views**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower class but are largely satisfied with your financial situation (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal over the next ten years, but you also think protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it slows economic growth and causes job losses. You moderately believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 3 on a scale of 1-10) and that taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is mostly essential for democracy (level 8). You also believe the state making people's incomes equal is mostly essential for democracy (level 8).  

You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You think it would be bad if less importance were placed on work in our lives. You moderately believe that hard work usually brings a better life (level 3) and that competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3). You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You also agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, but you disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You do not feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. Police or military interference with private life occurs quite frequently in your neighborhood, and drug sales are also quite frequent. However, racist behavior, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur frequently. You have not been a victim of crime in the past year, nor has anyone in your family. You have not carried a weapon for security reasons.  

#### **Trust and Social Relations**  
Friends are rather important in your life, but you never discuss political matters with them. You trust people you know personally somewhat but generally believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust your neighborhood very much. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, immigrants/foreign workers, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. However, you would not like to have people with AIDS, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people of a different race as neighbors.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, and you believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You think journalists provide fair coverage of elections very often. However, you never obtain information from email, mobile phones, the Internet, social media, or daily newspapers.  

#### **International and Institutional Views**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, the World Health Organization, universities, charitable or humanitarian organizations, women's organizations, environmental organizations, the armed forces, and churches. However, you do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), major companies, labor unions, the World Trade Organization, or the police.  

You believe the IMF headquarters are located in London and that India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council. You incorrectly believe Amnesty International deals with the destruction of historic monuments.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You consider religious faith, hard work, and tolerance and respect for other people important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider good manners, determination, perseverance, obedience, thrift, or unselfishness important for children.  

You believe stealing property, violence against others, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, claiming government benefits fraudulently, prostitution, homosexuality, abortion, suicide, and divorce (level 4) are never or rarely justified. You believe the death penalty is somewhat not justified (level 5).  

#### **Science, Technology, and Progress**  
You slightly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 6). You moderately agree that science and technology will bring more opportunities for the next generation (level 7) but also slightly agree that science breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 6). You believe the world is slightly worse off because of science and technology (level 4). You don’t mind if there was more emphasis on technology development or greater respect for authority.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8), though taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy. You feel you have a moderate amount of freedom of choice and control over your life (level 5). Your opinion about society is that it must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces. You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10) and a very substantial risk of bribery in public services (level 9).  

Despite your concerns, you would be willing to fight for your country if another war were to come. You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack, a civil war, a war involving your country, and not being able to give your children a good education. However, you are not worried much about losing your job or not finding one.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

#### **Final Reflections**

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 170 but currently live in this country, where you are a citizen. You are female, currently married, and live in a household of four people, including yourself, your spouse, and your parent(s)-in-law. You have one child. Your spouse belongs to the clerical group (e.g., secretary, clerk, office manager, civil servant, bookkeeper) and is or was a full-time employee (30 hours a week or more). Your spouse has completed short-cycle tertiary education.  

Your father was born in country 170 and belonged to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse). He has a Bachelor's degree or equivalent. Your mother was born in country 170 but has also completed post-secondary non-tertiary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family somewhat. One of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or needed medicine or medical treatment in the last 12 months, though you sometimes went without a cash income. You are very satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray once a day and attend religious services once a year. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, but not in life after death. You consider religious faith and good manners important qualities for children to learn, but you do not consider hard work, tolerance and respect for other people, determination, perseverance, thrift, or unselfishness important for them.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life after death rather than life in this world. However, you do not belong to any religious denomination or church. You completely disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not a member of any political party, professional association, labor union, environmental organization, women’s organization, art, music, or educational organization, sport or recreational organization, self-help or mutual aid group, or consumer organization. Politics is not very important in your life, and you never discuss political matters with your friends.  

You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also feel it would be very good to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections. You are neutral about whether people choosing their leaders in free elections is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), but you do not believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, religious authorities interpreting laws, the state making incomes equal, or people obeying their rulers are essential characteristics of democracy (level 1 on a scale of 1-10 for each).  

You disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do, and you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country. You disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You have no confidence in political parties at all and not much confidence in the press, environmental organizations, the armed forces, the police, the courts, the churches, the International Monetary Fund, labor unions, or women’s organizations. You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, banks, major companies, charitable or humanitarian organizations, universities, and elections.  

#### **Security, Trust, and Social Issues**  
You feel very secure these days and have a great deal of choice over the way your life turns out (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

You do not trust people of another religion or another nationality at all, and you do not trust people you know at all. You do not trust your neighborhood at all, though you note that police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood.  

Generally speaking, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You strongly believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality, though you do not feel very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, or the world. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration provides a better life for people from poor countries, though you agree it provides asylum to political refugees. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies.  

You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, people of a different religion, people who speak a different language, or people who have AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You work or worked for a private business or industry and are not the chief wage earner in your household. You disagree that work is a duty towards society, but you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is very important in your life.  

You largely believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly believe that competition is harmful (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, and social media daily, but you never obtain information from a daily newspaper. You believe TV news does not at all often favor the governing party in this country's elections, and you believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe journalists provide fair coverage very often of elections in this country.  

#### **Views on Violence, Corruption, and Justice**  
You believe political violence, violence against other people, stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, and suicide are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe abortion and the death penalty are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe prostitution is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10), and homosexuality is often justified (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and that most state and local authorities are involved in corruption. You believe there is a very high risk in this country of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in return for public service (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe ordinary people like yourself frequently have to pay bribes or give gifts to local officials to get services.  

#### **Elections and Governance**  
You usually vote in national and local elections, but you believe votes are not at all often counted fairly in this country's elections. You believe voters are bribed and threatened with violence at the polls very often, and you believe rich people buy elections very often. You believe election officials are fair very often, and voters are offered a genuine choice very often.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by giving people more say in important government decisions. You believe trying to make our cities and countryside more beautiful should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

#### **Science, Technology, and the Future**  
You strongly disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You believe the world is moderately worse off because of science and technology (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You completely disagree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You very strongly agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology and greater respect for authority.  

#### **Social and Personal Conduct**  
You do not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors. You neither agree nor disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. You disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, sign an electronic petition, join a boycott, donate to a group or campaign, encourage others to vote, encourage others to take political action online, search for information about politics online, or organize political activities, events, or protests online.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel it would be fairly bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections as a way of governing this country, but you also feel it would be very good to have the army rule or experts, not the government, make decisions for the country.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider equality more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces.

You believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption, and you believe journalists provide fair coverage very often of elections in this country.  

#### **International and Institutional Views**

#### **Freedom, Security, and Personal Choices**  
If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. However, if you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

You believe the government definitely should not have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet, to keep people under video surveillance in public areas, or to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.

About a war involving your country, you are not worried much, but about a civil war, you are worried very much. About a terrorist attack, you are not worried much.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). However, taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy.  

You feel close to your country, your continent, your county/region/district, your village/town/city, and the world. You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality.

You think giving people more say in government decisions is most important for the country, followed by fighting rising prices. You believe governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat essential for democracy (level 7), and that the state making incomes equal is mostly essential (level 8).  

You have no confidence in most institutions—banks, the press, the United Nations, the World Bank, the IMF, the WHO, the WTO, the European Union, the courts, the police, the armed forces, churches, universities, labor unions, charitable organizations, environmental organizations, and political parties. You do, however, have quite a lot of confidence in women’s organizations.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You describe yourself as upper middle class and are somewhat satisfied with your financial situation (level 6). You believe economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers. You largely believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more about luck and connections (level 9). You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy, and you don’t consider hard work an important quality for children to learn.  

You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. However, you disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems, and you strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You do not feel very secure these days. Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment occur very frequently in your neighborhood. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not carried a weapon. You have been a victim of crime in the past year, though no one else in your family has.  

If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would choose security. You believe the government probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas and to collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge. However, you believe the government definitely should not monitor all emails and online exchanges.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You believe immigration leads to social conflict and increases unemployment, but you also think the government should let anyone come who wants to. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, or offers a better life to people from poor countries. You do not mind having immigrants, people of a different race, religion, or language, or unmarried couples as neighbors, but you would not like to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

You do not trust people of another religion or nationality at all, nor do you trust people you know at all. However, you trust your neighborhood somewhat and disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, and cheating on taxes are never justified (level 1). You believe suicide and prostitution are sometimes justified (level 7), while abortion is somewhat not justified (level 5). You believe divorce is always justified (level 10), and that accepting a bribe is somewhat not justified (level 5).  

You consider good manners, obedience, and tolerance and respect for others important qualities for children to learn, but not hard work, determination, thrift, religious faith, or unselfishness.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from a daily newspaper daily, but from email, mobile phones, and the Internet less than monthly. You get information from social media monthly. You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and that most journalists and media people are corrupt. You have searched for information about politics online but would never encourage others to take political action online.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life (level 7) and rather happy. You feel you have considerable freedom of choice and control over your life (level 7). You believe there is extensive corruption in your country (level 9) and a high risk of bribery in public services (level 9). You worry a good deal about terrorist attacks, war involving your country, civil war, losing your job, and not being able to give your children a good education.  

You feel very close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; and your country, but not to your continent. Yet, you also feel close to the world. You are quite proud of your nationality, though you do not feel close at all to your continent.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, join a boycott, donate to a campaign, contact a government official, or encourage others to take political action. But you might sign an electronic petition, though you haven’t yet.  

In the end, you believe in freedom over equality, security over freedom, and that a stable economy is most important. You are a complex individual shaped by faith, skepticism, and a deep awareness of the world’s flaws—yet you hold onto hope for gradual improvement.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in this country (country 36), where your father was also born. Your mother, however, was born in country 380 and is an immigrant to this country. You are male, currently divorced, and live in a household with one other person, making you the chief wage earner. You have two children, and family is very important in your life. One of your main goals has been to make your parents proud, and you strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

Your father was a semi-skilled worker (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, carpenter), and you belong to the skilled worker group (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, electrician). You describe yourself as belonging to the working class. Financially, you are very dissatisfied with your household’s situation (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). Over the past year, you or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, or needed medicine, though you sometimes went without a cash income.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You believe in God, and God is moderately important in your life (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). However, you do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. Religion itself is not very important to you, and you do not belong to any religious denomination or church. You never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You consider yourself not a religious person but believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms and ceremonies. You also think religion is meant to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one, yet you do not trust people of another religion very much. Similarly, you do not trust people of another nationality very much. You consider tolerance and respect for others an important quality for children to learn, alongside good manners, hard work, determination, and perseverance. However, you do not value religious faith, obedience, thrift, or unselfishness as essential qualities for children.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are very proud of your country’s nationality and feel close to your country, county, region, and village or town. However, you do not feel very close to your continent or the world. You believe in democracy and think living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system but are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly oppose authoritarian rule—having a strong leader without parliament or elections, military rule, or a religious law-based system with no political parties or elections would be very bad in your view. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10). You also think women having the same rights as men is very essential (level 9), as is taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 8), equalizing incomes (level 8), and people obeying their rulers (level 8). However, you do not think religious authorities interpreting laws is essential (level 1).  

You are not a member of any political party and have no confidence in political parties at all. You occasionally discuss politics with friends, and politics is rather important in your life. You always vote in national and local elections and believe votes are counted fairly often, though you think voters are not at all often offered a genuine choice. You have no confidence in elections at all but believe election officials are not often fair, opposition candidates are not prevented from running, and voters are not threatened or bribed.  

#### **Security, Immigration, and National Concerns**  
You worry a good deal about a terrorist attack or a war involving your country but are not worried at all about a civil war. You are willing to fight for your country if necessary. You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and online exchanges and definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. However, you think the government probably should not collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

You agree that immigration increases unemployment, social conflict, and terrorism risks but also offers people from poor countries a better life. You support strict limits on foreign workers coming to your country and disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies. You do not mind having immigrants, people of a different race, religion, or language as neighbors but would not like to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Economic and Work Ethic**  
You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s top priority, followed by giving people more say in government decisions and fighting rising prices. A stable economy is most important to you. You largely believe competition is good (level 2) and that hard work usually brings a better life (level 2). You agree that work is a duty toward society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is rather important to you, but you think it would be bad if society placed less importance on work.  

You have no confidence in banks, the World Bank, or the International Monetary Fund at all and not much in major companies or the World Trade Organization. You believe there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8) but think few state or local authorities, journalists, or media people are involved in it.  

#### **Social and Moral Stances**  
You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, suicide, accepting bribes, and cheating on taxes are never justified (level 1). However, you think divorce (level 8), abortion (level 7), prostitution (level 6), and homosexuality (level 6) are somewhat justified. You neither agree nor disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

You disagree that men make better political leaders than women and that a university education is more important for boys than girls. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often and strongly disagree that women are less corrupt than men. You also disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems and think being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Media, Technology, and Science**  
You obtain information from email, mobile phones, daily newspapers, and the Internet less than monthly. You do not have much confidence in the press and believe TV news does not often favor the governing party. You think the world is much better off because of science and technology (level 8) and strongly disagree that science breaks down moral ideas (level 2). You moderately disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 3).  

#### **Community and Social Engagement**  
You trust your family completely and your neighborhood somewhat. Drug sales occur quite frequently in your area, but racist behavior, street violence, sexual harassment, and police/military interference with private life do not. You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or encourage others to vote or take political action—but you would never organize protests online or search for political information online. You have signed a petition before and might contact a government official.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, the World Health Organization, charitable groups, universities, women’s organizations, the armed forces, and the police—but not much in the courts, churches, or the United Nations. You have no confidence in NATO.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with life (level 7) and rather happy. You feel you have considerable freedom and control over your life (level 7) but do not feel very secure these days. You worry very much about losing your job and not being able to give your children a good education. Your opinion of society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms.  

You strongly value freedom over equality and security, believing in democracy, hard work, and personal responsibility—yet you remain cautious, trusting only those you know personally and always being careful in dealing with people.

You largely believe that competition is good (level 2 on a scale of 1-10) and that hard work usually brings a better life (level 2), with minimal attribution to luck and connections.  

You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You also believe work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. However, you don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

You strongly agree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You have a Master's degree or equivalent and have a great deal of confidence in universities.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreign Policy**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and provides asylum to political refugees, but you also believe immigration increases unemployment and the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration leads to social conflict.  

You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors, nor people of a different race. You find it hard to say whether immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the United Nations, and the European Union (or the relevant regional organization). You do not have very much confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), or the armed forces. You believe the IMF headquarters are located in Geneva and that India is not a member of the United Nations Security Council.  

#### **Law, Order, and Justice**  
You believe in strict enforcement of laws and order. You think the fight against crime is most important. You believe the government probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas but should not have the right to monitor all emails and other Internet communications or collect information about anyone without their knowledge.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the courts but not much in the police. You believe most state authorities are involved in corruption (level 7), though you think few local authorities and journalists/media people are corrupt. You believe there is a considerable risk of being held accountable for bribery in public services (level 7).  

You believe the following actions are justified:  
- Political violence (level 10)  
- Violence against other people (level 9)  
- Prostitution (level 9)  
- Stealing property (level 8)  
- Cheating on taxes (level 9)  
- Claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to (level 10)  
- Accepting bribes (level 9)  
- Divorce (level 10)  
- Suicide (level 6)  
- Abortion (level 5)  
- The death penalty (level 9)  
- Homosexuality (level 3)  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, and the Internet daily, from social media weekly, and from a daily newspaper weekly. You do not have very much confidence in the press. You have searched for information about politics online before.  

#### **Social and Community Life**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you trust people you know personally somewhat. You feel close to your village, town, or city, your continent, and the world, but not to your county, region, or district. You feel quite secure these days and have substantial freedom of choice and control over your life (level 8).  

You have attended peaceful demonstrations before and have signed petitions (both physical and electronic). You might join a boycott, donate to a group or campaign, or encourage others to vote or take political action online, though you haven’t done so yet. You might even organize political activities online.  

You have encouraged others to take action about political issues before. You have contacted a government official before.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 9) and would say you are very happy. You strongly disagree that moral rules are hard to follow nowadays (level 9) and believe the world is greatly better off because of science and technology (level 9), though you also strongly agree that science breaks down ideas of right and wrong (level 8).  

Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it comes to that, you would be willing to fight for your country. You are quite proud of your nationality.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development and greater respect for authority.  

You believe in a mix of strict governance, religious influence, and economic growth, with a strong emphasis on security over freedom. You are a complex individual with firm convictions, deeply rooted in both faith and pragmatism.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 630, and you are a citizen of this country. You are female, currently married, and live in a household of three people, including yourself. You have two children and do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your spouse belongs to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse) and is or was self-employed. Both your spouse and you hold a Bachelor's degree or equivalent.  

Your father was born in country 630 and belonged to the farm worker group (e.g., farm laborer, tractor driver), while your mother was also born in country 630 and has completed primary education. Your father has completed primary education as well. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income in the last 12 months.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day but attend religious services less often than once a year. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than to make sense of life after death. You consider yourself a religious person and are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections and women having the same rights as men are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, the state making people's incomes equal, and religious authorities interpreting the laws are not essential characteristics of democracy (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You are not a member of any political party, and politics is not very important in your life. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends, and you might encourage others to vote, but you would never encourage others to take action about political issues. You always vote in national and local elections. You believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country's elections, and voters are offered a genuine choice very often. However, you do not have very much confidence in elections.  

You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections, and you also feel it would be very bad to have the army rule. You feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections, and you also feel it would be fairly good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by fighting rising prices. You believe seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class and are largely satisfied with your household's financial situation (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You work or have worked for a government or public institution. You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society, and you think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You agree that people who don't work turn lazy.  

You disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You moderately believe that competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You somewhat believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life, with some attribution to luck and connections (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. However, you disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, and you agree that immigration increases unemployment. You find it hard to say whether immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries or increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration leads to social conflict or provides asylum to political refugees.  

You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, people of a different religion, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. However, you do not trust people of another religion very much, and you trust people of another nationality somewhat.  

#### **Security and Law Enforcement**  
You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet and to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. However, you believe the government definitely should not have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the police and the armed forces. Police or military interference with private life does not occur frequently in your neighborhood. You have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons and have not avoided carrying money for security reasons.  

#### **Trust in Institutions**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the United Nations, environmental organizations, banks, the World Health Organization, the courts, universities, women's organizations, and charitable or humanitarian organizations. You have a great deal of confidence in the churches and charitable or humanitarian organizations.  

However, you have no confidence in the World Bank, labor unions, or the European Union (or the relevant regional organization) at all. You do not have very much confidence in the press, major companies, the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization, or political parties.  

#### **Social and Moral Beliefs**  
You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You agree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against other people, claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled, cheating on taxes, accepting a bribe, and abortion are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe prostitution, divorce, suicide, and the death penalty are somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe homosexuality is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You consider religious faith, tolerance and respect for other people, determination and perseverance, and thrift (saving money and things) important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider good manners, hard work, obedience, or unselfishness important qualities for children to learn.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, social media, or your mobile phone. You obtain information from a daily newspaper weekly. You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in this country's elections, and you believe journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections in this country. You believe few of the journalists and media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Neighborhood and Safety**  
Racist behavior, drug sales, street violence and fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You do not trust your neighborhood very much. You would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors, but you do not mind having unmarried couples or people who have AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Global and Scientific Perspectives**  
You feel close to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; your continent; and your country. However, you do not feel very close to the world.  

You completely agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You neither agree nor disagree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation or that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Final Reflections**  
Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel quite secure these days and have a moderate amount of freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe there is a great deal of respect for individual human rights nowadays in your country, but you also believe there is considerable corruption (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl and that men make better political leaders than women. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems or that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

You believe in life after death, and you think it would be a good thing if there was greater respect for authority. You believe protecting the environment should be given priority, even if it causes slower economic growth and some loss of jobs.  

You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms.  

Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.

You consider good manners, tolerance and respect for others, determination, perseverance, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider hard work, obedience, thrift, saving money, or religious faith important for children.

You strongly disagree that a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections would be a good way to govern, though you feel it would be fairly good to have such a leader. You also feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, or to have the army rule.  

You are a member of a political party but are not active, and politics is rather important in your life. You always vote in national and local elections and believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country’s elections. You think having honest elections is very important and believe voters are not often threatened with violence or bribed at the polls. You have no confidence in political parties, the press, the police, the armed forces, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), or elections. You have quite a lot of confidence in the courts, universities, environmental organizations, labor unions, women’s organizations, and major companies. However, you have no confidence in the World Bank, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the churches, charitable or humanitarian organizations, or the International Monetary Fund.  

#### **Social and Economic Views**
