You disagree that immigration increases unemployment or leads to social conflict. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and provides asylum to political refugees. You believe the government should let anyone come who wants to work here, though you find it hard to say whether immigration offers a better life to people from poor countries or increases terrorism risks.  

#### **Security and Freedom**  
If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would choose freedom. But if you had to choose between freedom and security, you would choose security. You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all emails and online exchanges or keep people under video surveillance in public areas, but you think it probably should have the right to collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge.  

You are not worried at all about a terrorist attack but are worried a good deal about a war involving your country. You are not worried much about a civil war. You would not be willing to fight for your country if another war broke out.  

#### **Neighborhood and Society**  
You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, race, or language, or immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors. However, you would not like to have people with AIDS or drug addicts as neighbors. You do not mind heavy drinkers as neighbors.  

Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, street violence, and fights do not occur at all in your neighborhood. Drug sales and sexual harassment do not occur frequently. You trust your neighborhood somewhat and believe few local authorities are involved in corruption.  

#### **Work and Social Roles**  
You work (or worked) in the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse) for a private business or industry. You are the chief wage earner in your household. You strongly disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women and that men make better political leaders than women. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often.  

You agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, but you strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than a girl. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems. You agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Media and Information**  
You obtain information from the Internet daily but from email, social media, and mobile phones less than monthly. You never get information from a daily newspaper. You believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in elections and that journalists provide fair election coverage very often. You think few journalists and media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe stealing property, violence against others, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, suicide, abortion, and claiming unauthorized government benefits are almost never justified (level 2). You think prostitution is sometimes justified (level 7), divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5), and the death penalty is usually not justified (level 4).  

You slightly agree that it’s hard to decide which moral rules are right nowadays (level 5). You strongly disagree that having children is a duty towards society. You neither agree nor disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

#### **Activism and Engagement**  
You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or encourage others to take political action, though you would never organize political activities online. You have signed a petition before and might sign an electronic petition. You have donated to a group or campaign and have contacted a government official before.  

You are actively involved in an environmental organization and a consumer organization but are not a member of any art, music, educational, sport, recreational, self-help, or labor union groups.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
You feel close to your country, continent, and county/region but not to your village, town, or city—or the world. You think progress toward a less impersonal, more humane society is most important. You believe maintaining order in the nation is the second most important goal, while fighting rising prices is the top priority. You also think making cities and countryside more beautiful should be a key goal.  

You feel you have somewhat limited freedom and control over your life (level 4). You believe there is some corruption in your country but that it’s relatively limited (level 4), and there is a noticeable risk of bribery in public services (level 6). You generally think you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

All in all, you are a complex individual with strong convictions, a mix of liberal and conservative views, and a deep, though not always trusting, engagement with the world around you.

You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months, though you or your family rarely went without needed medicine or medical treatment. You are very satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You consider yourself an atheist and do not belong to any religious denomination or church. Religion is not at all important in your life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not believe in God, heaven, or hell. However, you believe in life after death. You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than to make sense of life after death.  

You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that work is a duty towards society, though you think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is very important in your life.  

You consider good manners, tolerance and respect for other people, hard work, and unselfishness as important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider obedience, determination, perseverance, thrift, or religious faith as important qualities for children.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not a member of any political party and have no confidence in political parties at all. Politics is not very important in your life, and you never discuss political matters with your friends. You are neutral about how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, though you also feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You strongly disagree with having a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections and feel it would be fairly bad to have the army rule.  

You believe having honest elections is very important for you, and you always vote in both national and local elections. You have encouraged others to vote before. You believe votes are counted fairly fairly often, election officials are fair fairly often, and voters are not often bribed or threatened with violence at the polls. However, you believe voters are not often offered a genuine choice in elections, and opposition candidates are not often prevented from running. You believe few of the state and local authorities are involved in corruption, and you think there is a moderate amount of corruption in your country (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe giving people more say in important government decisions is most important for the country, followed by fighting rising prices. A stable economy is most important to you, and you believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. You moderately believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You are neutral about whether governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, religious authorities interpreting laws, women having the same rights as men, the state making incomes equal, or people obeying their rulers are essential characteristics of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is slightly essential (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much. You agree that immigration leads to social conflict and increases unemployment, but you also agree that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees or increases the risks of terrorism.  

Despite your reservations, you do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different religion, race, or language, or even people who have AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You do not feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. You have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. A member of your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have also been a victim of crime in the past year.  

You believe police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood, nor do racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, fights, or sexual harassment occur there. You trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

#### **Views on Violence and Morality**  
You believe political violence, violence against other people, stealing property, claiming government benefits fraudulently, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and prostitution are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the death penalty is almost never justified (level 2), and suicide, divorce, and abortion are somewhat not justified (level 5). You believe homosexuality is always justified (level 10).  

You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples. You disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women and strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems and that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from email and a daily newspaper monthly. You do not have very much confidence in the press and believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in elections. You believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption and that journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections.  

#### **Institutional Trust and Global Views**  
You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund, major companies, universities, the armed forces, the police, the courts, labor unions, or charitable organizations. You have no confidence in churches at all. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, women's organizations, banks, and elections.  

You do not feel very close to your continent or the world but feel close to your country, county, region, or district, and village, town, or city. You are quite proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your country.  

#### **Future Concerns and Aspirations**  
You are worried a good deal about losing your job or not finding a job and about not being able to give your children a good education. However, you are not worried much about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, or a civil war.  

You believe protecting the environment should be given priority, even if it causes slower economic growth and job losses. You slightly agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7). You don’t mind if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

#### **Political Engagement and Activism**  
You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, sign a petition, sign an electronic petition, donate to a group or campaign, contact a government official, or encourage others to take action about political issues. You might also search for information about politics online or organize political activities online, though you have not done so yet.  

However, you would not be willing to fight for your country if another war were to come.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel you have substantial freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 8).  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. If you had to choose between freedom and equality, or freedom and security, you would consider freedom more important in both cases.  

You generally need to be very careful in dealing with people, though you trust those you know personally somewhat. Friends are rather important in your life, but you do not feel very close to them politically.  

You are a complex individual—proud of your country, skeptical of institutions, valuing freedom and hard work, yet cautious about trust and change. Your life is shaped by your family, your professional background, and your belief in gradual societal improvement.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 608, though both your parents were also born there, making you deeply rooted in your homeland. You are male, currently married, and live in a household of two people, including yourself. Your spouse belongs to the farm worker group (e.g., farm laborer, tractor driver) and has completed lower secondary education. They are or were a full-time employee, working 30 hours a week or more. You have four children, and family is very important in your life. You strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud, and you believe adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

Your father was a farm proprietor or farm manager, while both your parents had no formal education or only early childhood education. Despite this, you describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class. Financially, you are very satisfied with your household’s situation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), though you or your family sometimes went without enough food to eat and needed medicine or medical treatment in the last 12 months. However, you never went without safe shelter and rarely went without a cash income.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You pray several times a day, attend religious services more than once a week, and consider yourself a religious person. God is extremely important to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe in heaven, hell, and life after death. You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, though you trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having them as neighbors.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others, though you also think it helps make sense of life in this world rather than just the afterlife. You consider religious faith, good manners, obedience, hard work, and tolerance and respect for other people as important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not value determination, perseverance, thrift, or unselfishness as much.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are very proud of your country’s nationality and feel close to your village, town, city, county, region, and country—though not to your continent or the world at large. You believe in maintaining order in the nation and think the fight against crime is most important, followed by fighting rising prices. You have mixed feelings about democracy: while you feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system, you also believe it would be very good to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections. You even feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, and you would support the army ruling the country.  

You believe living in a democratically governed country is extremely important (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), yet you think votes are not often counted fairly, voters are bribed very often, and rich people buy elections frequently. You also believe opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often and that election officials are fair only fairly often. Despite this, you always vote in national and local elections and might encourage others to vote or take political action.  

You have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at all and not much in the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, or the World Trade Organization. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), banks, the armed forces, the courts, universities, labor unions, charitable organizations, political parties, and women’s organizations.  

#### **Security and Governance**  
You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and any other internet exchanges, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge. You worry a good deal about terrorist attacks and civil wars and are very much concerned about a potential war involving your country. If another war came, you would be willing to fight for your nation.  

You feel quite secure these days, and in your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur at all. Racist behavior does not occur frequently either. You have a great deal of confidence in the police and believe ordinary people rarely have to pay bribes for public services, though you also think there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You work or worked for a private business or industry and are the chief wage earner in your household. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you agree that work is a duty toward society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You somewhat believe people should take more responsibility for themselves but also see a role for government (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You think it would be good if less importance were placed on work in life, yet you disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You also disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer, and you agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. However, you believe a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You believe the government should prohibit people from other countries coming here to work, disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees, and agree that immigration leads to social conflict and increases terrorism risks. You would not like to have immigrants, foreign workers, drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Justice and Ethics**  
You believe stealing property, cheating on taxes, and claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to are almost never justified (level 2). Abortion is almost never justified (level 2), while suicide is rarely justified (level 3). Prostitution is rarely justified (level 3), and homosexuality is usually not justified (level 4). Divorce is sometimes justified (level 7), as is violence against others (level 7), accepting bribes (level 7), and the death penalty (level 7).  

#### **Media and Information**  
You never obtain information from email, the internet, social media, or your mobile phone. You get news from a daily newspaper less than monthly and believe most journalists and media people are corrupt. You do not have much confidence in the press and think TV news does not often favor the governing party.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 2 on a scale of 1-10), yet you also say you are very happy. You feel you have considerable freedom of choice (level 7) and believe our society must be gradually improved by reforms. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization, and politics is very important in your life, though you are not a member of any political, professional, environmental, or recreational organizations.  

You trust your family and neighborhood somewhat but are generally cautious in dealing with people. You believe in protecting the environment even at economic cost, yet you think less emphasis should be placed on technology. Science is not important in your daily life (level 9), though you moderately agree it creates opportunities for future generations (level 7).  

This is your life—rooted in faith, family, and country, shaped by struggle, and guided by a mix of tradition, authority, and cautious hope for the future.

You have a great deal of confidence in major companies and political parties.

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life (level 9) and rather happy. You feel you have a great deal of choice over how your life turns out (level 10). Your opinion about society is that the entire way it is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action. Yet, you also believe there is a great deal of respect for individual human rights in your country today.

You are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people, and also to make sense of life after death instead of life in this world. You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You completely agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your country, county, region, or district, as well as your village, town, or city. However, you do not feel very close to your continent or the world. You believe in democracy and feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country. Living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly disagree with having a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, or army rule.  

You are not a member of any political party, and politics is not very important in your life, though you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You believe votes are not often counted fairly, voters are not offered a genuine choice, voters are threatened with violence at the polls fairly often, and voters are bribed fairly often in this country's elections. You also believe election officials are not often fair, journalists do not provide fair coverage, and opposition candidates are not often prevented from running. You think rich people do not often buy elections, and you have quite a lot of confidence in elections.  

You describe yourself as belonging to the lower class and are largely dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in both government and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for government responsibility (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You feel it would be very good to have experts, not the government, make decisions for the country. You strongly agree that competition is good (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Economic and Work Ethic**  
You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. However, you strongly agree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl and that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women. You also strongly agree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems and that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. Still, you agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

#### **Security and Safety Concerns**  
You feel quite secure these days but have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, but you have been. You are worried very much about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, and a civil war. You also worry very much about losing your job or not finding one and not being able to give your children a good education.  

You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet and definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You also believe the government probably should have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Social Issues**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. However, you disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, leads to social conflict, or increases unemployment. You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees or offers a better life to people from poor countries. You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers or people of a different race as neighbors but do not mind having people of a different religion, people who speak a different language, unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, or people who have AIDS as neighbors.  

You do not trust people of another nationality at all and trust people of another religion somewhat. Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people, though you trust your neighborhood completely.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You strongly believe in traditional moral values. You believe stealing property, violence against other people, political violence, cheating on taxes, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, accepting bribes, prostitution, homosexuality, divorce, suicide, and abortion are never justified (all level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the death penalty is somewhat justified (level 6).  

You consider good manners, obedience, religious faith, and tolerance and respect for other people important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider hard work, determination, perseverance, thrift, or unselfishness important for children.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, social media, or daily newspapers. Instead, you obtain information from your mobile phone daily. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press and believe TV news does not often favor the governing party. You believe none of the journalists and media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Institutional Trust and Civic Engagement**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund (IMF) (whose headquarters you correctly identify as Washington DC), banks, major companies, churches, universities, and the armed forces. You have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, environmental organizations, charitable or humanitarian organizations, courts, police, labor unions, political parties, women’s organizations, and the press.  

You always vote in national and local elections but would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, sign an electronic petition, join a boycott, donate to a group or campaign, encourage others to vote, encourage others to take political action online, contact a government official, or organize political activities online. You would, however, be willing to fight for your country if there were another war.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 6 on a scale of 1-10) and consider yourself very happy. You feel you have a fair amount of freedom of choice and control over your life (level 6). Your opinion about society is that it must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces. You believe protecting freedom of speech is most important for the country, followed by maintaining order in the nation. You also think making cities and countryside more beautiful should be the most important goal for the next ten years.  

Despite the challenges, you remain committed to your faith, family, and work, upholding traditional values while navigating the complexities of modern life.

You also agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You also agree that it is a duty toward society to have children.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Workers**  
About people from other countries coming to work here, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. However, you would not like to have people with AIDS, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, leads to social conflict, or increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration provides a better life for people from poor countries or increases unemployment.  

#### **Trust and Security**

You do not trust people of another nationality very much, people you know very much, or your neighborhood very much. Generally, you feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Media and Information**  
You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, social media, or a daily newspaper. You do not have very much confidence in the press and believe all journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You also believe journalists do not at all often provide fair coverage of elections and that TV news does not at all often favor the governing party.  

#### **Corruption and Governance**  
You believe there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and that most state and local authorities are involved in corruption. However, you think ordinary people like yourself rarely have to pay bribes for public services. You believe there is a moderate risk of being held accountable for bribery (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe the following are never justified:  
- Political violence (level 1 on a scale of 1-10)  
- Stealing property (level 1)  
- Prostitution (level 1)  
- Homosexuality (level 1)  
- Abortion (level 1)  
- Suicide (level 1)  
- Claiming government benefits fraudulently (level 1)  
- Cheating on taxes (level 1)  
- Accepting bribes (level 1)  
- Violence against others (level 1)

#### **Social and Civic Engagement**

- Attend a peaceful demonstration  
- Join a boycott  
- Sign a petition (electronic or otherwise)  
- Donate to a group or campaign  
- Contact a government official  
- Encourage others to vote or take political action  
- Organize political activities online  
- Search for political information online  

#### **Global and Institutional Confidence**  
You do not have very much confidence in:  
- The North Atlantic Treaty Organization  
- The World Bank  
- The United Nations  
- The International Monetary Fund  
- The World Trade Organization  
- The European Union (or relevant regional organization)  
- Environmental organizations  
- Major companies  
- Banks  
- The armed forces  
- The police  
- The courts  
- Universities  
- Labor unions  
- Political parties  
- Charitable or humanitarian organizations  
- Women’s organizations  

However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and consider yourself rather happy. You feel you have a great deal of choice over how your life turns out (level 10).  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is most important, and you think it would be good if there was greater respect for authority and more emphasis on technology development.  

You consider good manners, tolerance, respect for others, and obedience important qualities for children to learn, but not hard work, determination, perseverance, thrift, unselfishness, or religious faith.  

You worry a good deal about a terrorist attack, losing your job, not being able to give your children a good education, and very much about a war involving your country or a civil war.  

Despite your concerns, you hold firm to your beliefs, values, and the importance of family, religion, and personal freedom in shaping your life.

You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all emails and other information exchanged on the Internet, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, or collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe stealing property is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10), violence against other people is rarely justified (level 3), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is almost never justified (level 2), cheating on taxes if you have a chance is usually not justified (level 4), and someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is rarely justified (level 3).  

You believe prostitution is somewhat not justified (level 5), homosexuality is usually not justified (level 4), divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5), abortion is somewhat not justified (level 5), and the death penalty is somewhat not justified (level 5). You believe suicide is somewhat justified (level 6).  

#### **Personal Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel you have considerable freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 7). You are moderately satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 7).  

You feel close to your country and the world but do not feel very close to your continent, county, region, or district, or your village, town, or city.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. In your opinion, progress toward a society in which ideas count more than money is most important. You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. You believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology (level 6).

You neither agree nor disagree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 5). You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

You somewhat disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 7). Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

#### **Global and National Perspectives**  
You are very proud to be of your country's nationality and feel close to your country. However, you do not feel very close to your continent, county, region, district, village, town, city, or the world.

You have never lived with your parents or in-laws.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You or your family have never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine, or a cash income in the last 12 months. You are very satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). One of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud.  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Protestant denomination and consider yourself a religious person, though religion is not very important in your daily life. God is moderately important to you (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God but do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death. You never or practically never attend religious services and never pray. You are a member of a church or religious organization but are not active in it.  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and trust people of another religion somewhat. You do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors. You disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

Morally, you believe stealing property, violence against others, accepting bribes, cheating on taxes, and claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe prostitution, homosexuality, divorce, and abortion are always justified (level 10), while suicide is somewhat justified (level 6). You slightly agree that deciding which moral rules to follow can be difficult nowadays (level 5).  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You are very proud of your country’s nationality and feel close to your village, town, or city, though not to your county, region, district, continent, or the world. You believe in a democratic political system and consider living in a democratically governed country absolutely important (level 10). You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law or the army rule. However, you also think it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who doesn’t have to bother with parliament and elections.  

You believe votes are counted fairly very often, election officials are fair fairly often, voters are offered a genuine choice very often, and journalists provide fair election coverage fairly often in your country. You have a great deal of confidence in elections and the courts, and you always vote in national and usually in local elections. However, you would never encourage others to vote or take political action, nor would you organize political activities or attend peaceful demonstrations. You might sign a petition, donate to a campaign, or contact a government official but have not yet signed an electronic petition.  

You are not a member of any political party, professional association, labor union, environmental organization, consumer organization, or self-help group. You are not part of any art, music, educational, sport, or recreational organization. Politics is rather important in your life, and you occasionally discuss political matters with friends.  

#### **Economic and Social Views**  
You work or have worked for a government or public institution and belong to the service group (e.g., restaurant owner, police officer, waitress, barber, caretaker). You moderately believe that hard work usually brings a better life (level 3) and that competition is good (level 2). You disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, and you don’t mind if less importance is placed on work in life. You neither agree nor disagree that work is a duty toward society.  

You believe economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers somewhat. A stable economy is most important to you, followed by fighting rising prices. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal over the next decade.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in banks, major companies, and the World Trade Organization. You moderately believe the government should take some responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 3). You disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems. You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for boys than girls.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Policy**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work in your country but also agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees and offers people from poor countries a better life. You disagree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, or increases terrorism risks. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.  

You have a great deal of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the armed forces, and the World Health Organization. You have quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, and the press. You do not have much confidence in the United Nations or the European Union (or the relevant regional organization).  

About a war involving your country, you are worried a good deal, but about a civil war or terrorist attack, you are not worried much or at all.  

#### **Technology, Science, and Society**  
You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10) and strongly agree that the next generation will have more opportunities due to them (level 8). You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development and greater respect for authority. You strongly disagree that science breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong (level 4) and that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 2).  

You obtain information from the Internet weekly but never from social media. You get information from email, mobile phones, and daily newspapers less than monthly. You have searched for political information online.  

#### **Social Values and Neighborhood**  
Friends and leisure time are very important in your life. You trust people you know personally completely and your neighborhood somewhat. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, language, or religion, or people with AIDS as neighbors. However, you would not like heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors.  

In your neighborhood, police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur at all. You feel quite secure these days.  

#### **Education and Children’s Upbringing**  
You have completed lower secondary education. You consider good manners, tolerance, respect for others, and thrift important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider hard work, religious faith, obedience, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness important for children.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5) but consider yourself rather happy. You feel you have substantial freedom of choice and control over your life (level 8). Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay and that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

You are completely satisfied with how the political system functions in your country (level 10) and believe there is minimal corruption (level 3). You think none of the journalists, state authorities, or local officials are involved in corruption and that ordinary people never have to pay bribes for services.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality or freedom and security, you would always choose freedom.

#### **Social and Economic Beliefs**  
You believe freedom is more important than equality if you had to choose, but security is more important than freedom. You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by fighting rising prices and ensuring strong defense forces. You believe women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), but you think women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office in this country.

You strongly disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You agree that work is a duty towards society and that having children is also a duty.  

You believe both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on hard work (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come here to work. You find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, increases the risks of terrorism, or offers a better life to people from poor countries. You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors.  

#### **Trust and Security Concerns**  
You generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust people of another nationality at all. You trust people you know personally somewhat and your neighborhood somewhat. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons.  

You are worried very much about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, a civil war, losing your job, and not being able to give your children a good education. You feel quite secure these days.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You have no confidence in the press at all and believe most journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections, and TV news does not often favor the governing party.

#### **Views on Science, Technology, and Morality**  
You slightly disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and slightly agree that because of science, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). However, you completely agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You completely agree that nowadays, one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Corruption and Governance**  
You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and that most state authorities are involved in corruption, though few local authorities are. You believe ordinary people always have to pay bribes, give gifts, or do favors to get services. You think there is a very high risk of being held accountable for bribery (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International Views and Organizations**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the United Nations, the World Bank, and universities. You have quite a lot of confidence in the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, banks, major companies, the armed forces, the police, and women's organizations. You have no confidence in environmental organizations, labor unions, courts, elections, or charitable organizations.  

You believe the IMF headquarters are located in London and that France is not a member of the United Nations Security Council. You believe Amnesty International deals with human rights.  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Environment**  
Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, or people who speak a different language as neighbors. However, you would not like to have people with AIDS, drug addicts, or heavy drinkers as neighbors.  

#### **Personal Happiness and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel you have a great deal of choice over the way your life turns out (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe in life after death and think progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important. You feel very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and the world.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You have mixed views on competition, seeing it as slightly good (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on technology development but a bad thing if there was greater respect for authority.  

You are actively involved in a self-help or mutual aid group and a consumer organization but are not active in any sport, recreational, art, music, or educational organization. You are a member of a labor union but not active.

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy, and you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Religion and Beliefs**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Protestant denomination. You consider yourself a religious person, and God is very important in your life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a week. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than to make sense of life after death. You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You do not believe in heaven, hell, or life after death.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You work or worked for a private business or industry and belong to the clerical group (e.g., secretary, clerk, office manager, civil servant, bookkeeper). You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and that people who don’t work turn lazy. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives, and you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You believe both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on hard work (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You have mixed views about competition being good or harmful, with a slight inclination toward seeing it as good (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years, followed by fighting rising prices as the second most important.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country. You believe living in a country that is governed democratically is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), along with people obeying their rulers (level 10), women having the same rights as men (level 10), and governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 8).  

However, you believe votes are not often counted fairly in this country's elections, voters are not at all often offered a genuine choice, and election officials are fair fairly often. You believe TV news favors the governing party very often, rich people buy elections very often, and voters are bribed very often. You believe all journalists and media people, all state authorities, and all local authorities are involved in corruption. You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You are not a member of any political party and have not much confidence in political parties. You feel it would be very good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country. You also feel it would be very good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You strongly agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do, though you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country.  

#### **Social and Cultural Values**  
You consider good manners, hard work, religious faith, tolerance and respect for other people, determination, perseverance, obedience, thrift, and unselfishness as important qualities for children to learn. You agree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents and that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You agree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and you disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

#### **Immigration and Neighbors**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, offers people from poor countries a better life, but also increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism.  

You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, people of a different religion, people who speak a different language, unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, or people who have AIDS as neighbors. However, you do not mind having drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You do not feel very secure these days. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. A member of your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have also been a victim of a crime in the past year.  

You believe violence against other people, stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and suicide are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe prostitution and abortion are somewhat not justified (level 5), while divorce is always justified (level 10).  

#### **Media and Information**  
You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, or social media. You obtain information from a daily newspaper weekly. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, though you believe journalists provide fair coverage very often of elections in this country.  

#### **International and Institutional Views**  
You have a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund (whose headquarters you believe are in Washington DC), the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the European Union (or the relevant regional organization), banks, major companies, universities, charitable or humanitarian organizations, women's organizations, labor unions, the armed forces, and the courts. You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, environmental organizations, the police, elections, and the churches.

#### **Political Participation and Activism**  
Politics is rather important in your life, and you occasionally discuss political matters with your friends. You always vote in national and local elections but would never encourage others to vote, never sign a petition (electronic or otherwise), never join a boycott, never donate to a group or campaign, never contact a government official, never encourage others to take political action online, never organize political activities online, and never search for political information online. You might attend a peaceful demonstration.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You strongly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You believe claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is almost always justified (level 9). You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10), and you completely agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 10). However, you also completely agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 10).  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You feel you have extensive freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 9). You are very proud to be of your country's nationality, and if it came to war, you would be willing to fight for your country. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but you are worried very much about a war involving your country, a terrorist attack, and a civil war.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You trust people you know personally completely, your neighborhood completely, people of another religion somewhat, and people of another nationality somewhat. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a complex mix of traditional and modern values, shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You are **female**, currently **married**, and live in a household of **4 people**, including yourself. You do not live with your parents or in-laws. Your **spouse** belongs to the **skilled worker group** (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, printer, seamstress, tool and die maker, electrician) and is or was a **full-time employee** (30 hours a week or more). You have **2 children**, and **family is very important** in your life.  

Both your **mother and father** were born in **country 203**, though your mother was also born in your current country. Your **father** belonged to the **skilled worker group**, just like your spouse. Your **mother, father, and spouse** have all completed **lower secondary education**.  

You describe yourself as belonging to the **lower class** and are **moderately satisfied with your household’s financial situation** (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You or your family **never went without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income** in the last 12 months.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You **work or worked for a private business or industry** and belong to the **service group** (e.g., restaurant owner, police officer, waitress, barber, caretaker). You are **not the chief wage earner** in your household.  

You **moderately believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves**, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You also **moderately believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections**, placing limited importance on hard work (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **strongly believe that competition is good** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and **disagree that work is a duty towards society**. You **strongly disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time**, and you **don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work in our lives**.  

#### **Political and Social Beliefs**  
You are **very proud** of your country’s nationality and feel **very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and the world**. You **feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system** and that **living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You **strongly disagree** with having a **strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections**, a **system governed by religious law without political parties or elections**, or **the army ruling** as ways of governing the country.  

You **always vote in national and local elections** and believe **having honest elections is very important**. You think **votes are counted fairly very often**, **voters are offered a genuine choice very often**, **election officials are fair fairly often**, and **voters are not at all often threatened with violence or bribed** in elections. You also believe **opposition candidates are not at all often prevented from running**, **rich people do not at all often buy elections**, and **TV news does not often favor the governing party**.  

You **occasionally discuss political matters with friends** but are **not a member of any political party, professional association, labor union, environmental organization, consumer organization, or self-help/mutual aid group**. You have **quite a lot of confidence in elections** but **not very much confidence in political parties**.  

You **have attended peaceful demonstrations before** and **signed a petition**, but you **would never organize political activities, events, or protests online, encourage others to take political action online, or contact a government official**. You **might join a boycott, sign an electronic petition, or donate to a group or campaign** but have not done so yet.  

You **believe protecting freedom of speech is most important for the country**, followed by **fighting rising prices** and **making cities and countryside more beautiful**. You **prioritize economic growth and creating jobs**, even if the environment suffers to some extent.  

#### **Views on Equality, Gender, and Society**  
You **strongly disagree that men make better political leaders than women**, that **a university education is more important for a boy than a girl**, that **being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay**, or that **children suffer when a mother works for pay**. You **believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often** and that **women having the same rights as men is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems** and **strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples**.  

You **strongly disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children** and that **adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents**. You also **disagree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud**.  

#### **Immigration and Multiculturalism**  
You **do not trust people of another religion or nationality very much**, but you **do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors**. You **would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers, heavy drinkers, or drug addicts as neighbors**.  

You believe the **government should let people from other countries come to work as long as there are jobs available**, but you **find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies, increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, increases the risks of terrorism, provides asylum to political refugees, or offers a better life to people from poor countries**.  

#### **Security and Crime**  
You **feel quite secure these days** and have **avoided carrying much money for security reasons** but have **not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons**. **No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year**, and you have **not been a victim of crime either**.  

You believe **police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood**. You **trust your neighborhood somewhat** and **trust your family completely**.  

You **generally need to be very careful in dealing with people** but **trust people you know personally somewhat**.  

#### **Religion and Spirituality**  
You are an **atheist**, do **not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death**, and **never or practically never attend religious services or pray**. **Religion is not at all important in your life**, and **God is very unimportant** (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You do **not belong to any religious denomination, church, or religious organization**.  

You **disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one** and **disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science**. You believe the **basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of following religious norms and ceremonies** and to **make sense of life in this world instead of life after death**.  

#### **Technology, Science, and Media**  
You **obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, and social media daily**, and from a **daily newspaper monthly**. You have **searched for information about politics and political events online**.  

You **very strongly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) but **completely agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You **believe the world is very better off because of science and technology** (level 8 on a scale of 1-10) and think it would be **good if there was more emphasis on technology development**.  

You are **neutral about whether one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong** (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have **quite a lot of confidence in the press** and believe **few journalists and media people are involved in corruption**.  

#### **International and Institutional Trust**  
You have a **great deal of confidence in the United Nations, North Atlantic Treaty Organization, World Bank, World Health Organization, World Trade Organization, International Monetary Fund, charitable/humanitarian organizations, women’s organizations, and universities**. You also have **quite a lot of confidence in the European Union (or relevant regional organization), banks, major companies, environmental organizations, armed forces, courts, and police**.  

You **do not have very much confidence in churches, labor unions, or political parties**.  

You **believe China is not a member of the United Nations Security Council** and that **Amnesty International deals with human rights**.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Views**  
You believe:  
- **Political violence is never justified** (level 1).  
- **Violence against other people is never justified** (level 1).  
- **Stealing property is rarely justified** (level 3).  
- **Claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to is rarely justified** (level 3).  
- **Accepting a bribe is rarely justified** (level 3).  
- **Cheating on taxes is somewhat not justified** (level 5).  
- **Prostitution is always justified** (level 10).  
- **Homosexuality is always justified** (level 10).  
- **Divorce is always justified** (level 10).  
- **Abortion is always justified** (level 10).  
- **Suicide is almost always justified** (level 9).  
- **The death penalty is rarely justified** (level 3).  

You **somewhat disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow** (level 7).  

#### **Personal Happiness and Outlook**  
You are **rather happy**, **very satisfied with your life as a whole these days** (level 9), and **extremely satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country** (level 9). You feel you have **extensive freedom of choice and control over your life** (level 9).  

You **would not be willing to fight for your country in a war** and are **not worried at all about a terrorist attack, civil war, losing your job, or not being able to give your children a good education**. You are **not worried much about a war involving your country**.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that **it must be gradually improved by reforms**. You believe there is **extensive corruption in your country** (level 9) and a **considerable risk of bribery in public services** (level 7), but you also believe **few state and local authorities are involved in corruption** and that **ordinary people like yourself never have to pay bribes for services**.  

You consider **determination, perseverance, obedience, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn**, but **not hard work, thrift, good manners, tolerance, respect for others, or religious faith**.  

You **don’t mind if there was greater respect for authority** but **strongly value freedom over equality and security**.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You believe stealing property, violence against other people, prostitution, homosexuality, suicide, abortion, and cheating on taxes are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). #### **Technology and Science**  
You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology and greater respect for authority.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, social media, or daily newspapers. You obtain information from your mobile phone monthly. You believe TV news favors the governing party very often in this country's elections and that journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel you have substantial freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).

Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You moderately disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 8 on a scale of 1-10).

You have never had a job, are not a member of any professional, political, environmental, sport, recreational, art, music, educational, self-help, mutual aid, labor union, or consumer organization. However, you have signed a petition before.  

You would never donate to a group or campaign, search for information about politics online, or encourage others to take action about political issues.

You believe the death penalty is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children.  

You feel it would be very good to have experts, not government, make decisions according to what they think is best for the country.  

You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).

All these experiences, beliefs, and values shape who you are today.

You describe yourself as belonging to the **lower middle class** and are **neither satisfied nor dissatisfied** with your financial situation or life as a whole (level 5). Ultimately, you are **rather happy**, with a **moderate sense of freedom and control** over your life (level 5), and you are **very satisfied with how the political system functions** in your country (level 8).
