**Your Background Story**  

### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in this country, though your father was born in country 417, while your mother was born in this country as well. You live regularly in a household of four people, not including your parents or in-laws. You are male, currently single, and have no children. Your father belonged to the unskilled worker group (e.g., laborer, porter, unskilled factory worker, cleaner), and your mother completed upper secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You or your family have never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine, or a cash income in the last 12 months. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you yourself have not been a victim either.  

### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination and consider yourself a religious person. God is very important in your life (level 8 on a scale of 1-10), and you pray once a day. You attend religious services once a month. However, religion is not very important in your daily life. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others, and you also believe it is meant to make sense of life after death rather than life in this world.  

You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, though you trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors. You strongly believe in moral absolutes—stealing, violence, bribery, cheating on taxes, suicide, abortion, divorce, prostitution, and homosexuality are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10 for each). You somewhat disagree that deciding which moral rules to follow is difficult nowadays (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

### **Political and Social Views**  
You are not a member of any political party, professional association, labor union, or any other organization (art, music, educational, environmental, consumer, self-help, or religious). Politics is not at all important in your life, though you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are somewhat satisfied with how the political system functions in your country (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You feel it would be very bad to have a democratic political system, a system governed by religious law without parties or elections, or experts making decisions instead of the government. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have a strong leader who bypasses parliament or the army rule. You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by giving people more say in government decisions. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the country’s top priority over the next decade.  

You strongly believe people should take more responsibility for themselves (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and that hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on the same scale). You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty toward society. You also believe work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

### **Views on Governance and Security**  
You believe the government should have the right to monitor all emails and internet exchanges, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and collect information about anyone without their knowledge. You consider security more important than freedom if forced to choose. You are worried a good deal about terrorist attacks, war involving your country, and civil war.  

You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), with most state and local authorities, as well as journalists, involved in it. You have quite a lot of confidence in the armed forces, the United Nations, environmental organizations, banks, major companies, charitable organizations, universities, and women’s organizations. However, you do not have much confidence in the police, courts, or political parties.  

### **Views on Immigration and Society**  
You agree that immigration leads to social conflict and increases unemployment, but you also believe it offers people from poor countries a better life. You think the government should let people come to work as long as jobs are available, though you disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies or provides asylum to political refugees. You do not mind having immigrants, people of a different race, or those who speak a different language as neighbors.  

However, you would not like to have unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You feel close to your village, town, or city, as well as your county or region, but not to your country, continent, or the world.  

### **Education, Work, and Gender Roles**  
You have completed upper secondary education and have never had a job. You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that a university education is more important for a boy than a girl, that men make better political leaders, and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it will likely cause problems. However, you also agree that women are less corrupt than men and that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

### **Media and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone daily, the internet weekly, and social media weekly. You never get information from email or daily newspapers. You have quite a lot of confidence in the press, though you believe TV news does not often favor the governing party in elections.  

### **Civic Engagement and Voting**  
You always vote in national and local elections but would never encourage others to vote, sign an electronic petition, contact a government official, or engage in political activism online. You believe votes are not often counted fairly, voters are not offered a genuine choice, and election officials are not fair. Despite this, you have quite a lot of confidence in elections and believe having honest elections is rather important.  

### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life (level 6 on a scale of 1-10) and rather happy. You feel you have a fair amount of freedom and control over your life (level 6). You strongly believe in defending society against subversive forces and that people must be careful in dealing with others. Leisure time is rather important to you, but you don’t mind if there was less emphasis on work or greater respect for authority.  

You are quite proud of your nationality, and if war came, you would be willing to fight for your country. You trust your neighborhood somewhat and people you know personally somewhat, but generally, you believe you must be very careful in dealing with others.

### **Your Background Story**

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You feel very close to your country, county, region, or district, and you are very proud of your nationality. You also feel close to your continent and the world. You strongly believe in democracy, considering it absolutely important to live in a democratically governed country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system and very bad to have a system governed by religious law, a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, or army rule. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections and women having the same rights as men are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (both level 10). However, you believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 4), religious authorities interpreting laws (level 1), and the state making incomes equal (level 3) are not essential.

You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty toward society. You think it would be a bad thing if less importance were placed on work in our lives. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You disagree that immigration increases unemployment or the risk of terrorism but find it hard to say whether immigration leads to social conflict.  

#### **Security and Law Enforcement**  
You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not carried a weapon. You feel quite secure these days and are not worried about a terrorist attack, war involving your country, or civil war. You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by giving people more say in government decisions. You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, armed forces, and courts but no confidence in political parties, labor unions, or the press.  

You believe the government definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas and collect information about anyone without their knowledge. However, you think the government probably should not monitor all emails and online exchanges.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, and daily newspapers weekly but from social media less than monthly. You do not have much confidence in the press and believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often. You think few journalists and media people are corrupt.  

#### **Social and Moral Attitudes**  
Friends are rather important in your life, while family is not very important. Leisure time is rather important, and you neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first. You strongly disagree that having children is a duty toward society. You believe political violence, stealing property, violence against others, claiming government benefits fraudulently, cheating on taxes, and accepting bribes are never justified (all level 1). #### **Final Reflections**

You believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology (level 6) and slightly agree that future generations will have more opportunities due to it (level 6). However, you very strongly agree that knowing about science is not important in your daily life (level 9).

### **Your Comprehensive Backstory**  

#### **Personal Background and Family**  
You were born in country 422, though you now reside in your current country of citizenship, where you were also raised. Your father was born in country 422, while your mother was born in this country. Both of your parents hold Bachelor’s degrees or equivalent, and your father belonged to the professional and technical group (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse). You currently live with your own parent(s) in a household of five people, where you are not the chief wage earner.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a cash income, or needed medicine in the last 12 months, though you sometimes went without a safe shelter. You describe yourself as belonging to the upper middle class but are very dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Religious and Moral Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination and consider yourself a religious person. Religion is very important in your life, and God is extremely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a month. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, but not in life after death. You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, though you trust people of another religion completely.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to others, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife. You strongly agree that nowadays, one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You are a member of a church or religious organization but are not active in it.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
Politics is very important in your life, and you frequently discuss political matters with your friends. You are not a member of any political party and would vote for another party if there were a national election tomorrow. You usually vote in both national and local elections, though you have no confidence in elections and believe votes are not at all often counted fairly. You believe voters are not often threatened with violence at the polls but are bribed very often, and election officials are not at all often fair.  

You feel it would be fairly bad to have a democratic political system and very bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. Instead, you feel it would be fairly good to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections, and very good to have the army rule. You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by fighting rising prices.  

You strongly believe that the entire way society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action. You have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the International Monetary Fund, or the World Trade Organization. You also do not have much confidence in the European Union or relevant regional organization.  

#### **Social and Economic Perspectives**  
You strongly believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). However, you also believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is mostly not essential to democracy (level 2). You strongly believe that competition is good (level 1) and that hard work usually brings a better life (level 1).  

You agree that work is a duty towards society and should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You don’t mind if there was less importance placed on work in life. You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You also agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women, though women are less corrupt.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Neighbors**  
You believe the government should let people from other countries come to work as long as there are jobs available, but you disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, or leads to a better life for people from poor countries. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment or the risks of terrorism.  

You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, people of a different religion, people who speak a different language, unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who have AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Security, Surveillance, and Corruption**  
You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and other internet exchanges, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge. You do not feel very secure these days and believe police or military interference with private life occurs quite frequently in your neighborhood.  

You believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6) and that most journalists, media people, state authorities, and all local authorities are involved in corruption. You also believe ordinary people frequently have to pay bribes for services (level 7).  

#### **Technology, Science, and the Future**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the internet, and social media daily, but never from a daily newspaper. You believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology (level 6) and moderately agree that it will bring more opportunities for the next generation (level 7). You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development and greater respect for authority.  

#### **Personal Values and Lifestyle**  
You are currently single and have no children. You agree that having children is a duty towards society. Leisure time is very important to you, and friends are very important in your life. You trust people you know personally completely and your neighborhood completely, though you generally feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

You consider good manners, hard work, tolerance, respect for others, and thrift important qualities for children to learn, but not religious faith, obedience, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life (level 7) and rather happy. However, you feel you have no choice at all over how your life turns out (level 1). You are very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and even the world. You are quite proud of your nationality and feel progress toward a less impersonal, more humane society is most important.  

You strongly disagree that science breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong (level 2) and agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You slightly agree that knowing about science is not important in your daily life (level 6).  

You would never engage in political activism—whether signing petitions, attending demonstrations, joining boycotts, contacting officials, or encouraging others to take action. You believe in maintaining order, even if it means sacrificing some freedoms, but if forced to choose, you value freedom over equality and security.  

This is your story—shaped by faith, tradition, skepticism of democracy, and a deep belief in the need for radical change.

However, you **agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees** and **disagree that immigration increases the risks of terrorism**.  

You **do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors**, nor do you mind having people of a **different race, religion, or language** as neighbors. However, you **would not like to have drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people with AIDS as neighbors**.  

#### **Security and Law Enforcement**  
You **feel quite secure these days** and have **avoided carrying much money for security reasons**. You have **not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons**. You **believe the government probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas** but **probably should not have the right to monitor all emails and other Internet communications** or **collect information about anyone without their knowledge**.  

You **do not have very much confidence in the police or the courts** but have a **great deal of confidence in the armed forces**. You **believe police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood**, and **racist behavior, sexual harassment, and drug sales do not occur frequently** where you live.  

#### **Views on Corruption and Governance**  
You **believe there is extensive corruption in your country** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and that **most state and local authorities are involved in corruption**. You think **few journalists and media people are corrupt**, but you **believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often**. You **believe rich people do not often buy elections**, but you also think there is a **very substantial risk of bribery in public services** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **largely believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for** (level 2 on a scale of 1-10) and **strongly agree that taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is very essential for democracy** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International and Global Perspectives**  
You **do not feel very close to your continent** and **do not feel close at all to the world**. You have **quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, the IMF, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), and universities**. You **believe the IMF headquarters are in Washington DC** and that **India is not a member of the UN Security Council**.  

You **would be willing to fight for your country in a war** and are **worried a good deal about a war involving your country** and **very much about a civil war or terrorist attack**.  

#### **Technology and Media Habits**  
You **obtain information from a daily newspaper daily**, from your **mobile phone weekly**, from the **Internet weekly**, and from **social media weekly**, but you **never obtain information from email**. You **would never search for political information online** and **disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life** (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **believe the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology** (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) but **very strongly agree that science and technology will create more opportunities for the next generation** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You **moderately disagree that science breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong** (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are **very satisfied with your life as a whole** (level 9 on a scale of 1-10) and **rather happy**. You feel you have a **great deal of choice over how your life turns out** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you **generally need to be very careful in dealing with people** and **do not trust people you know very much**.  

Your opinion about society is that **the entire way our society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action**. Yet, despite this, you are **satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days** (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

This is your story—shaped by your beliefs, experiences, and the world around you.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 792, and both your mother and father were also born there. Your father belonged to the semi-skilled worker group (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, cannery worker, carpenter, sheet metal worker, baker), while you belong to the farm worker group (e.g., farm laborer, tractor driver). Your parents completed lower secondary education, and your mother is an immigrant to this country, just like you. Your father is also an immigrant.  

You are currently married, and your spouse has a Bachelor’s degree or equivalent. Your spouse has never had a job but is or was a full-time employee (30 hours a week or more). You live with your own parent(s) in a household of four people, including yourself. You have no children.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income in the last 12 months. A member of your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, though you have not.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination and consider yourself a religious person. Religion is rather important in your life, and God is very important to you (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God, heaven, and hell, as well as life after death. You attend religious services once a month and pray several times each week.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies. You also believe religion is meant to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death. You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one.  

You do not belong to any church or religious organization, but you trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You are an immigrant to this country and a citizen. You feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). However, you are not at all proud of your country's nationality and do not feel very close to it.  

You are actively involved in a political party and a labor union. You usually vote in national and local elections and believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections. You have encouraged others to vote before and have contacted a government official before. You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, or sign a petition. You might also organize political activities, events, or protests online but have not done so yet.  

You believe having honest elections is rather important, and you think voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often. However, you also believe voters are threatened with violence at the polls fairly often, TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and rich people buy elections fairly often. You believe election officials are not often fair, and journalists do not often provide fair coverage of elections.  

You are not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe there is no respect at all for individual human rights nowadays in your country and that most state and local authorities, as well as journalists and media people, are involved in corruption. You believe there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and a noticeable risk of bribery (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Economic and Social Perspectives**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the working class and work or worked for a private business or industry. You are the chief wage earner in your household and are somewhat satisfied with your financial situation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You largely believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10) and that the state making people's incomes equal is somewhat essential (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You agree that people who don't work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You strongly agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is not very important in your life. You somewhat believe that hard work doesn't generally bring success—it's more a matter of luck and connections, though hard work has some importance (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer and that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. However, you strongly disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
As an immigrant, you believe immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also agree that immigration leads to social conflict, increases unemployment, and increases the risks of terrorism.  

You think the government should let people from other countries come to work as long as there are jobs available. You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Freedom**  
You do not feel very secure these days. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important. If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider equality more important.  

You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, a civil war, losing your job or not finding a job, and not being able to give your children a good education.  

You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, or collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Trust**  
You trust your neighborhood completely. Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence and fights, and sexual harassment do not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

You trust people you know personally somewhat and people of another nationality somewhat. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Technology and Information**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from social media daily, from email weekly, and from a daily newspaper weekly. You believe the world is moderately better off because of science and technology (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You moderately agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) but slightly agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You completely disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe stealing property, prostitution, homosexuality, violence against other people, claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled, cheating on taxes, accepting a bribe, and suicide are never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe abortion and divorce are usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). The death penalty is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **International and Institutional Views**  
You have no confidence in the World Bank, the World Health Organization, or the International Monetary Fund at all. You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the United Nations, the press, environmental organizations, the armed forces, the churches, labor unions, the World Trade Organization, women's organizations, charitable or humanitarian organizations, or the courts.  

You do not have very much confidence in the police but have quite a lot of confidence in banks, major companies, universities, the European Union (or the relevant regional organization), political parties, and elections.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. However, you feel you have no choice at all over the way your life turns out (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important. You believe seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You believe protecting freedom of speech is the second most important for the country, and giving people more say in important government decisions is most important.  

You are a member of a professional association, an art, music, or educational organization, a sport or recreational organization, and an environmental organization—though you are not active in any of them. You are not a member of any self-help or mutual aid group, consumer organization, or church or religious organization.  

You consider good manners, hard work, tolerance and respect for other people, determination and perseverance, and not being selfish (unselfishness) important qualities for children to learn.  

Of course, we all hope that there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.

**Your Background Story**  

**Demographics and Family Life**  
You were born in country 703, though both your parents were born in this country. You are female, currently widowed, and live regularly in a household with three people, including yourself. You do not live with your parents or in-laws. You have two children, and family is very important in your life. You agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud, and you believe adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. Your father belonged to the farm worker group (e.g., farm laborer, tractor driver), and both your parents completed primary education. You work or worked for a government or public institution and belong to the clerical group (e.g., secretary, clerk, office manager, civil servant, bookkeeper). You are not the chief wage earner in your household.  

**Religious Beliefs and Practices**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one and that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and you pray several times a day. God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You attend religious services more than once a week and are actively involved in a church or religious organization. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life after death instead of life in this world.  

**Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You are a citizen of this country and are quite proud of your nationality. You feel very close to your country, continent, county, region, or district, village, town, or city, and even the world. You always vote in national and local elections and believe having honest elections is very important. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and are not a member of any political party, professional association, labor union, environmental organization, consumer organization, or self-help or mutual aid group. You have no confidence in political parties at all.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system and believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor, women having the same rights as men, and the state making people's incomes equal are absolutely essential characteristics of democracy (all level 10). However, you are very dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 2 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe voters are counted fairly fairly often, election officials are fair fairly often, and voters are offered a genuine choice very often in elections. However, you also believe TV news favors the governing party very often, rich people buy elections fairly often, and voters are bribed very often. You think most journalists, state authorities, and local authorities are involved in corruption.  

**Social and Economic Beliefs**  
You largely believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You also agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You consider hard work, thrift, saving money, and good manners important qualities for children to learn but do not value tolerance, respect for others, obedience, determination, perseverance, or unselfishness as much.  

You believe freedom is more important than equality but security is more important than freedom. You strongly agree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are right (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You feel it would be very bad to have the army rule and fairly bad to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections or a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections.  

**Views on Immigration and Foreigners**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work here. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, offers people from poor countries a better life, increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees. However, you do not mind having immigrants, foreign workers, people of a different race, religion, or language, or even people with AIDS as neighbors.  

**Trust and Security**  
You trust your family and neighborhood completely and people you know personally completely. You trust people of another religion or nationality somewhat but generally feel you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

**Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, mobile phones, daily newspapers, the Internet, or social media. You do not have much confidence in the press and believe journalists do not often provide fair election coverage.  

**Science, Technology, and the Environment**  
You slightly agree that knowing about science is not important in your daily life (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You completely agree that the world is better off because of science and technology (level 10) and that there will be more opportunities for the next generation due to science (level 10). However, you also completely agree that science breaks down people’s ideas of right and wrong (level 10). You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development but also believe economic growth and job creation should be prioritized even if the environment suffers.  

**Personal Well-being and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), but taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel quite secure these days and are very satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 9). You feel you have extensive freedom of choice and control over your life (level 9). Leisure time is very important to you, and you think it would be good if there was less importance placed on work.  

**Final Thoughts**  
You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by fighting rising prices. You also believe progress toward a society where ideas count more than money is most important. You strongly oppose political violence, stealing, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, suicide, abortion, divorce, prostitution, and homosexuality (all level 1 on justification scales). You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as others.  

You are not worried about losing your job or not finding one, nor about your children’s education. However, you are very worried about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, and a civil war. You would not be willing to fight for your country if war came.  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a complex mix of hope and skepticism about the world around you.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in this country, though your father was born in country 422, while your mother was born in this country as well. You live regularly in a household of five people, including yourself, residing with your own parent(s). Your father was a semi-skilled worker (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, carpenter), and both your parents completed primary education. You are male, currently single, and have no children.  

Family is very important in your life, and you strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You also strongly believe that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You trust your family completely, and you or your family have never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine, or a cash income in the past year. However, you are completely dissatisfied with your household’s financial situation.  

#### **Religion and Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination, though religion is not very important in your daily life. You never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not believe in hell, but you do believe in heaven and life after death. God is very important in your life (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms and ceremonies. You also think religion is meant to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife.  

You do not trust people of another religion very much, though you do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors. You disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and also disagree that religion is always right in conflicts with science.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and have no confidence in political parties, elections, the press, the United Nations, the World Bank, the IMF, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the European Union, environmental organizations, women’s organizations, charitable organizations, labor unions, churches, or major companies. However, you have a great deal of confidence in the armed forces.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system but believe votes are not often counted fairly, election officials are not fair, opposition candidates are often prevented from running, and voters are frequently bribed. You also think rich people buy elections often. Despite this, you believe having honest elections is rather important and that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10).  

You would vote for another party if there were a national election tomorrow, though you never vote in national or local elections. You occasionally discuss political matters with friends but would never attend a peaceful demonstration, sign a petition, encourage others to vote, contact a government official, or organize political activities online.  

You believe political violence is never justified (level 1), and you feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, a strong leader who bypasses parliament, or the army ruling the country. You think living in a democratically governed country is somewhat important (level 6).  

#### **Economic and Work Ethic**  
You work or have worked for a private non-profit organization and are not the chief wage earner in your household. You strongly agree that work is a duty toward society and that people who don’t work turn lazy. You also agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You think it would be bad if less importance were placed on work in life.  

You believe economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers somewhat. You consider a stable economy most important and think fighting rising prices should be the country’s main focus, followed by maintaining order. You somewhat believe that hard work usually brings a better life, though luck and connections also play a role (level 4).  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are quite proud of your country’s nationality and feel very close to your country, county, region, and village or town. However, you do not feel close to your continent or the world.  

You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work here. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies and agree that it leads to social conflict and increases unemployment and terrorism risks. However, you also acknowledge that immigration offers people from poor countries a better life. You would not like to have immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.  

You do not trust people of another nationality at all.  

#### **Security and Surveillance**  
You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, and a civil war. You do not feel very secure these days and are worried very much about losing your job or not finding one.  

You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and other internet communications, keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and collect information about anyone in the country without their knowledge. You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons and have not carried a weapon.  

#### **Social and Moral Values**  
You consider good manners, tolerance, respect for others, determination, perseverance, and thrift important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not value hard work, religious faith, obedience, or unselfishness as essential traits for children.  

You believe stealing property, violence against others, homosexuality, divorce, abortion, and suicide are never justified (level 1). You think cheating on taxes is never justified (level 1) but that claiming government benefits you are not entitled to is often justified (level 8). You also believe accepting a bribe is somewhat justified (level 6) and that the death penalty is somewhat justified (level 6).  

You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, but you disagree that men make better political leaders than women. You also disagree that if a woman earns more than her husband, it causes problems. You strongly disagree that a university education is more important for boys than girls.  

#### **Technology and Media**  
You obtain information daily from email, your mobile phone, the internet, and social media but never from a daily newspaper. You believe the world is much better off because of science and technology (level 8) and think it would be good if more emphasis were placed on technological development. You moderately agree that science and technology will create more opportunities for the next generation (level 7) and disagree that science breaks down moral ideas (level 3).  

You have no confidence in the press and believe all journalists and media are involved in corruption. You also think journalists do not provide fair election coverage.  

#### **Corruption and Governance**  
You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10) and that all state and local authorities are corrupt. You think the risk of being held accountable for bribery is very high (level 10).  

You somewhat believe the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, though with some emphasis on individual responsibility (level 4). You think taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is mostly essential for democracy (level 8) and that making incomes equal is somewhat essential (level 7).  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5), though you are not at all happy. You feel you have a fair amount of freedom and control over your life (level 6). You believe our society must be gradually improved by reforms.  

You would be willing to fight for your country if another war came, despite your worries about conflict. You hope for stability, economic growth, and a functioning democracy, even as you distrust most institutions and remain deeply skeptical of those outside your immediate circle.

You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income in the last 12 months. You or your family rarely went without needed medicine or medical treatment in the past year.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You pray several times a day and attend religious services once a week. You are actively involved in a church or religious organization.  

You strongly agree that when science and religion conflict, religion is always right. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death.  

You consider religious faith, good manners, tolerance and respect for other people, obedience, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider hard work, determination, perseverance, or thrift as important qualities for them.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are female and describe yourself as a religious person. You are a member of a political party but are not active, and politics is rather important in your life. You are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, but you also feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You would not mind if there was greater respect for authority. You feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections.  

You believe giving people more say in important government decisions is most important for the country, followed by maintaining order in the nation. You believe trying to make our cities and countryside more beautiful should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important.  

You largely believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that the state making people's incomes equal is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). However, you believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is slightly not essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You are neutral about whether people choosing their leaders in free elections is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that religious authorities ultimately interpreting the laws is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), and that people obeying their rulers is also slightly essential (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that women having the same rights as men is slightly not essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe living in a country that is governed democratically is of somewhat low importance to you (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You believe votes are not often counted fairly in this country's elections, voters are not often offered a genuine choice, and election officials are fair fairly often. You believe voters are not often threatened with violence at the polls, and voters are not at all often bribed. You believe rich people do not often buy elections, and opposition candidates are not at all often prevented from running.  

You usually vote in national and local elections, but you would never encourage others to vote, never sign a petition, never join a boycott, never attend a peaceful demonstration, never donate to a group or campaign, never encourage others to take action about political issues, and never contact a government official.  

#### **Trust and Security**  
You do not trust people of another religion or another nationality at all. You do not trust people you know very much, and you generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. You do not trust your neighborhood very much, though you feel quite secure these days.  

You believe the government definitely should have the right to monitor all e-mails and any other information exchanged on the Internet, to keep people under video surveillance in public areas, and to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons, nor have you avoided carrying money for security reasons. No one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either.  

#### **Views on Work, Gender, and Society**  
You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do, but you disagree that on the whole, women are less corrupt than men. You believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office fairly often in this country.  

You disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems. You agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer.  

You agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, but you disagree that work is a duty towards society. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Relations**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should prohibit people from coming. You disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, leads to social conflict, increases unemployment, increases the risks of terrorism, or provides a better life for people from poor countries.  

You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Bank, the United Nations, the International Monetary Fund, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the European Union (or the relevant regional organization), or the armed forces.  

#### **Media and Information Habits**  
You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, social media, or a daily newspaper. You do not have very much confidence in the press and believe most journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe journalists do not at all often provide fair coverage of elections in this country, and TV news does not often favor the governing party.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe stealing property is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), suicide is never justified (level 1), abortion is rarely justified (level 3), homosexuality is rarely justified (level 3), prostitution is almost never justified (level 2), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is usually not justified (level 4), someone accepting a bribe in the course of their duties is usually not justified (level 4), cheating on taxes if you have a chance is somewhat not justified (level 5), divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5), and political violence is somewhat not justified (level 5).  

You slightly disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Environment**  
You do not mind having unmarried couples living together as neighbors, heavy drinkers, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, or immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors. However, you would not like to have people of a different religion, people who have AIDS, or drug addicts as neighbors.  

Police or military interference with private life does not occur at all in your neighborhood. Racist behavior, drug sales, street violence and fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood.  

#### **Science, Technology, and the Future**  
You slightly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is greatly better off because of science and technology (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You neither agree nor disagree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), nor that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 5).  

You don't mind if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

#### **Corruption and Governance**  
You believe there is a moderate amount of corruption in your country (level 5 on a scale of 1-10) and a moderate risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in return for public service (level 5). You believe most of the state authorities, local authorities, and journalists/media people are involved in corruption.  

You believe ordinary people like yourself or people from your neighborhood never have to pay a bribe, give a gift, or do a favor to local officials and service providers to get the services they need.  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel you have a great deal of choice over the way your life turns out (level 10).  

You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality, though you do not feel close at all to your village, town, or city; your county, region, or district; your country; your continent; or the world.  

#### **Concerns and Fears**  
You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack, a civil war, losing your job or not finding a job, and not being able to give your children a good education (worried very much). However, you are not worried much about a war involving your country.  

Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would not be willing to fight for your country.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe in maintaining strong religious and family values while supporting a mix of democratic and authoritarian governance structures. You prioritize security, order, and moral integrity in your personal and political life.

You also believe in protecting freedom of speech as the second most important national goal, after fighting rising prices.  

You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy but disagree that work should always come first over spare time. You neither agree nor disagree that work is a duty towards society. You think it would be good if less importance were placed on work in life.

However, you also think it increases unemployment, social conflict, and terrorism risks. You feel quite secure these days but have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have never carried a weapon. However, sexual harassment occurs quite frequently.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe violence against others, stealing property, cheating on taxes, and accepting bribes are never justified (level 1). You think suicide is somewhat justified (level 6), prostitution sometimes (level 7), and abortion, divorce, and homosexuality always (level 10). The death penalty is rarely justified to you (level 3). You claim government benefits you’re not entitled to is often justified (level 8).  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and slightly disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 4). You think the world is neither better nor worse because of science (level 5).  

#### **International and Institutional Trust**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, NATO, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund, charitable organizations, and banks. You have no confidence in the press, churches, universities, labor unions, women’s organizations, or major companies.  

#### **Life Satisfaction and Outlook**  
Taking all things together, you are not very happy and are somewhat dissatisfied with your life (level 4). #### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination, and religion is rather important in your life. God is extremely important to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10), and you believe in God, heaven, hell, and life after death. You strongly agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, and you do not trust people of another religion at all. However, you do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.

You attend religious services only on special holy days, and you pray only on those days as well. You do not belong to any church or religious organization.

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your country, county, region, or district, as well as your village, town, or city. However, you do not feel very close to your continent or the world.  

You believe in democracy and feel it would be very good to have a democratic political system governing this country. You strongly believe that living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You consider having honest elections rather important and believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country's elections. You always vote in both national and local elections.  

You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10 on a scale of 1-10), as is women having the same rights as men (level 10). You also believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is an absolutely essential characteristic of democracy (level 10). However, you think that religious authorities interpreting the laws (level 3), the state making people's incomes equal (level 3), and people obeying their rulers (level 2) are not essential for democracy.  

You are extremely satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country these days (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You have no confidence in political parties at all and are not a member of any political party. Politics is not at all important in your life, and you never discuss political matters with your friends.  

You feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, a strong leader who bypasses parliament and elections, or the army ruling the country. You also think it would be fairly bad to have experts, not the government, make decisions for the country.  

#### **Economic and Work Ethic**  
You strongly agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty towards society. You also believe work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You somewhat believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with some emphasis on individual responsibility (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You also somewhat believe that competition is good, with some concerns about its harm (level 4).  

You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You also agree that, on the whole, men make better political leaders than women, though you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country.  

You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay and that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer.  

#### **Security, Law, and Order**  
You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by fighting rising prices. You also think the fight against crime is most important. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons but have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for such reasons.  

You trust your neighborhood somewhat and believe that police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, fights, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You also believe that ordinary people rarely have to pay bribes for services.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the police and a great deal of confidence in the armed forces, courts, and elections. You believe that voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls, opposition candidates are not prevented from running, and rich people do not often buy elections. However, you think voters are bribed very often in this country's elections.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Relations**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should let people come as long as there are jobs available. You disagree that immigration increases unemployment or the risks of terrorism, but you find it hard to say whether immigration fills important job vacancies or leads to social conflict.  

You disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees but agree that it offers people from poor countries a better life. You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors. You do not trust people of another nationality at all.  

You have no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization at all but have quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank, World Health Organization, and International Monetary Fund. You have a great deal of confidence in the United Nations, European Union (or relevant regional organization), and Amnesty International, which you believe deals with human rights.  

#### **Technology, Science, and Environment**  
You never obtain information from email, the Internet, social media, or your mobile phone. You obtain information from a daily newspaper monthly. You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and very strongly agree that because of science, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 9). However, you completely agree that knowing about science is not important in your daily life (level 10).  

You slightly disagree that science breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 4). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on technology development.  

You have a great deal of confidence in environmental organizations and believe protecting the environment should be prioritized, even if it slows economic growth and causes job losses. You are not a member of any environmental organization.  

#### **Social and Moral Values**  
You consider tolerance and respect for other people, hard work, determination, perseverance, and not being selfish important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider obedience, thrift, saving money, good manners, or religious faith important for children.  

You believe in strict moral conduct: stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, prostitution, divorce, abortion, suicide, and the death penalty are almost never justified (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe political violence and violence against others are usually not justified (level 2 and 4, respectively).  

You would not like to have unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You do not mind having people of a different race or language as neighbors.  

#### **Personal Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are largely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are very happy. You feel you have considerable freedom of choice and control over your life (level 7).  

You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. Leisure time is not very important in your life, and you do not feel very close to the world.  

You believe trying to make our cities and countryside more beautiful should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You generally need to be very careful in dealing with people and do not trust people you know very much. However, you trust your family completely.  

You are not worried at all about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, a civil war, losing your job, or not being able to give your children a good education.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, or freedom and security, you would consider freedom more important. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it came to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

This is your life—rooted in faith, family, hard work, and a deep belief in democracy, even as you navigate the complexities of modern society with caution and conviction.
