Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You strongly agree that one of your main goals in life has been to make your parents proud. You also strongly agree that adult children have the duty to provide long-term care for their parents.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Practices**  
Religion is very important in your life, and you belong to the Muslim denomination. You consider yourself a religious person, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in heaven, hell, and life after death. You attend religious services more than once a week and pray several times a day.  

You believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies instead of to do good to other people. You also believe the basic meaning of religion is to make sense of life after death rather than to make sense of life in this world.  

You agree that religion is right when it conflicts with science. You do not belong to any church or religious organization, but you have quite a lot of confidence in churches.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
Politics is not very important in your life, and you are not a member of any political party. You never discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, and you believe living in a democratically governed country is of somewhat high importance to you (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You also feel it would be fairly good to have a system governed by religious law in which there are no political parties or elections. You believe that people choosing their leaders in free elections is mostly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that religious authorities ultimately interpreting the laws is somewhat essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have no confidence in political parties, the press, the United Nations, the World Bank, the International Monetary Fund, the World Trade Organization, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the World Health Organization, or labor unions at all. You have quite a lot of confidence in environmental organizations, women’s organizations, charitable or humanitarian organizations, and banks.  

You believe having honest elections is very important for you, and you think votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections. However, you also believe opposition candidates are prevented from running fairly often, rich people buy elections fairly often, and journalists do not at all often provide fair coverage of elections. You believe voters are not often threatened with violence at the polls, voters are not often bribed, and voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often.  

You believe there is considerable corruption in your country (level 7 on a scale of 1-10) and that there is a very substantial risk of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in return for public service (level 9 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Economic and Work Values**  
You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society and that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You strongly believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives.  

You largely believe that competition is good, with minimal concerns about its harm (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy. You strongly agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women. You agree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women do, though you believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often in this country.  

You are largely dissatisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). About losing your job or not finding a job, you are worried very much. You also worry very much about not being able to give your children a good education.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work in your country. You agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism. However, you also agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and offers people from poor countries a better life. You find it hard to say whether immigration provides asylum to political refugees.  

You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors, but you would not like to have people who speak a different language, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people who have AIDS as neighbors. You do not mind having people of a different religion or race as neighbors.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe political violence is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), violence against other people is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), stealing property is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), cheating on taxes is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), suicide is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), and accepting a bribe is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe abortion is usually not justified (level 4 on a scale of 1-10), divorce is somewhat not justified (level 5 on a scale of 1-10), and the death penalty is sometimes justified (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is rarely justified (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Security and National Identity**  
You feel very secure these days. You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons, and no one in your family has been the victim of a crime in the past year. You have not been the victim of a crime in the past year either.  

You are quite proud to be of your country's nationality and feel very close to your country, your continent, your county/region/district, your village/town/city, and the world.  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider equality more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

You believe making sure this country has strong defense forces should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years. Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

#### **Technology and Science**  
You never obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, social media, or a daily newspaper. You believe the world is neither better nor worse off because of science and technology (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You slightly disagree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 4 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

#### **Social and Neighborhood Life**  
Friends are very important in your life, and you trust people you know personally completely. You also trust your neighborhood completely. Racist behavior does not occur at all in your neighborhood, but drug sales and street violence occur quite frequently.  

Leisure time is very important in your life, but you are not a member of any sport, recreational, art, music, educational, environmental, self-help, mutual aid, consumer, or professional organization.  

#### **Parenting and Values for Children**  
You consider good manners, hard work, determination/perseverance, thrift (saving money and things), and religious faith important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider tolerance and respect for other people, unselfishness, or obedience important qualities for children to learn.  

You strongly agree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You disagree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer. You neither agree nor disagree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it's almost certain to cause problems.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel you have a fair amount of freedom of choice and control over the way your life turns out (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people. You trust people of another religion somewhat but do not trust people of another nationality very much.  

Your opinion about society is that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces. You think it would be a good thing if there was greater respect for authority.  

You never vote in local elections but usually vote in national elections. You would never sign a petition, join a boycott, attend a peaceful demonstration, donate to a group or campaign, encourage others to vote, encourage others to take action about political issues, or contact a government official.  

In your opinion, a stable economy is most important, and you believe fighting rising prices is most important for the country. You believe that economic growth and creating jobs should be the top priority, even if the environment suffers to some extent.  

You largely believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure that everyone is provided for, with minimal emphasis on individual responsibility (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You also believe that the state making people's incomes equal is slightly essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

You agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income in the last 12 months.  

You are neutral about whether women having the same rights as men is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You disagree that on the whole, women are less corrupt than men.  

You somewhat disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 7 on a scale of 1-10).  

This is your story—rooted in faith, family, and a strong sense of duty, shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You believe stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, prostitution, homosexuality, abortion, suicide, divorce (almost never), and political violence are never or almost never justified (level 1 or 2 on a scale of 1-10). You do not mind unmarried couples living together as neighbors.  

You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You agree that men make better political leaders than women but also believe women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often.  

**Life Satisfaction and Outlook**  
Taking all things together, you are not at all happy and are completely dissatisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You feel you have a moderate amount of freedom of choice and control over your life (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You moderately believe that hard work usually brings a better life, with limited attribution to luck and connections (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly believe that government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and that our present society must be valiantly defended against all subversive forces.  

**Final Thoughts**  
You never vote in national or local elections, never sign petitions, never attend demonstrations, never contact government officials, and never encourage others to vote or take political action. Politics is not at all important in your life, and you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with how the political system functions (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe fighting rising prices is most important for the country, followed by maintaining order and achieving a stable economy. You think a high level of economic growth should be the country’s most important goal over the next ten years.  

Despite your struggles, you hold firm to your beliefs, values, and identity, finding strength in your faith, family, and sense of duty.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 360, but you now live in this country as a citizen, where you were also raised. You are female, currently married, and belong to the Muslim denomination. Religion is very important in your life—God holds the highest importance (level 10), and you pray several times a day. You attend religious services once a week and strongly believe that your religion is the only acceptable one. You believe in God, heaven, hell, and life after death, and you consider the basic meaning of religion to be following religious norms and ceremonies rather than doing good for others.  

You live in a household of five people, including yourself, and you are not the chief wage earner. Your spouse belongs to the unskilled worker group (e.g., laborer, porter, unskilled factory worker, cleaner) and is or was a full-time employee (30 hours a week or more). Your spouse has completed upper secondary education, just like you. You have three children, and family is very important in your life. You strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. Both your mother and father were born in country 360, though your mother was also born in this country. Your father belonged to the unskilled worker group and completed lower secondary education, while your mother completed primary education.  

You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and work (or worked) for a private business or industry. You belong to the service group (e.g., restaurant owner, police officer, waitress, barber, caretaker) and are actively involved in a professional association. You are completely satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 10) and have never gone without enough food, safe shelter, needed medicine, or a cash income in the past year.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
You consider yourself a religious person and believe that religion should always be right when it conflicts with science. You strongly agree that competition is good (level 1) but also believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections (level 10). You feel you have substantial freedom of choice and control over your life (level 8) and are rather happy overall. All things considered, you are very satisfied with your life (level 9).  

You believe in traditional family values: you agree that adult children have a duty to care for their parents, that having children is a duty toward society, and that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples and would not like to have unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors. You believe divorce is almost never justified (level 2), abortion is never justified (level 1), and suicide is never justified (level 1).  

You consider religious faith, tolerance, respect for others, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn but do not value hard work, good manners, obedience, determination, perseverance, or thrift as much.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
Politics is very important in your life, and you occasionally discuss political matters with friends. You are not a member of any political party, labor union, or environmental organization, but you are a member of a church or religious organization (though not active) and an art, music, or educational organization (also not active). You always vote in national and local elections and believe votes are counted fairly very often, though you also think rich people buy elections very often. You have encouraged others to vote and might encourage political action, but you would never organize protests or contact a government official.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system but also believe a strong leader who doesn’t have to bother with parliament and elections would be a good way to govern. You even feel it would be fairly good to have the army rule. You strongly believe the entire way society is organized must be radically changed by revolutionary action.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important, followed by fighting rising prices and ensuring a stable economy. You think seeing people have more say in their jobs and communities should be the most important goal for the next decade. You have quite a lot of confidence in elections but believe voters are bribed very often and that opposition candidates are prevented from running very often. You also think most state and local authorities are involved in corruption and that corruption is abundant in your country (level 10).  

#### **Security and Governance**  
You prioritize security over freedom and believe the government should have the right to monitor all emails and internet exchanges, collect information about anyone without their knowledge, and keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You avoid carrying much money for security reasons and have not carried a weapon. You worry very much about terrorist attacks, war involving your country, and losing your job. You are willing to fight for your country if necessary.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, courts, armed forces, and universities but not much in the press, political parties, labor unions, the United Nations, or the European Union. You have a great deal of confidence in banks, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, environmental organizations, women’s organizations, and churches. You also have quite a lot of confidence in NATO, major companies, charitable organizations, and the IMF.  

#### **Immigration and Social Issues**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on foreign workers coming to your country, as immigration leads to social conflict and increases unemployment. However, you disagree that immigration increases terrorism risks and agree that it provides asylum to political refugees and offers people from poor countries a better life. You do not mind having immigrants, people of a different race, or people who speak a different language as neighbors but do not trust people of another religion or nationality at all.  

#### **Technology and Media**  
You obtain information daily from your mobile phone, the internet, social media, and daily newspapers but never from email. You believe the world is much better off because of science and technology (level 10) and completely agree that science will create more opportunities for the next generation. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development. However, you also believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often and that none of the journalists or media people are involved in corruption.  

#### **Justice and Morality**  
You believe in strict moral codes: stealing property, violence against others, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, and prostitution are never justified (level 1). You support the death penalty (level 8) and think there is a very high risk of being held accountable for bribery in your country (level 10). You slightly agree that it’s hard to decide which moral rules to follow nowadays (level 5).  

#### **Community and Trust**  
You feel close to your village, town, or city and your country but not to your continent, county, region, district, or the world. You trust your family completely but not people you know or your neighborhood very much. Street violence occurs quite frequently in your area, but racist behavior, drug sales, sexual harassment, and police/military interference with private life do not occur at all.  

You believe ordinary people frequently have to pay bribes for services, and you generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. Yet, despite these challenges, you feel quite secure these days and are somewhat satisfied with how the political system functions (level 6).  

This is your life—shaped by faith, family, and a deep concern for security and order, yet marked by contradictions between tradition and modernity, trust and suspicion, hope and disillusionment.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal Identity and Family Life**  
You were born in this country, though your father was born in country 496, while your mother was born in this country. You are female, currently single, and have no children. You live with your own parent(s) in a household of two people, where you are not the chief wage earner. Your father was a skilled worker (e.g., foreman, motor mechanic, printer, seamstress, tool and die maker, electrician), while you belong to the semi-skilled worker group (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, cannery worker, carpenter, sheet metal worker, baker). Both your parents completed lower secondary education.  

Family is very important in your life, and you trust your family completely. You strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud. You or your family never went without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine, or a cash income in the last 12 months. You are completely satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is not at all important in your life, and you do not belong to any religious denomination or church. You do not believe in God, heaven, hell, or life after death. You attend religious services once a year, pray less often than once a year, and believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to others rather than follow religious norms and ceremonies. You also believe religion is meant to make sense of life in this world rather than the afterlife.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You completely disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is a lot better off because of science and technology (level 10) and completely agree that science and technology will create more opportunities for the next generation (level 10).  

You consider good manners, hard work, and determination/perseverance important qualities for children to learn, but you do not value religious faith, tolerance and respect for others, obedience, thrift, or unselfishness as essential traits.  

#### **Political Views and Civic Engagement**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and are quite proud of your country's nationality. You feel very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and even the world.  

You are actively involved in a political party, a professional association, a labor union, a consumer organization, a self-help or mutual aid group, and an art, music, or educational organization. You are also a member (though not active) of a sport/recreational organization and an environmental organization.  

You occasionally discuss political matters with friends, have attended peaceful demonstrations, and have encouraged others to vote or take political action. You have organized political activities online and might join a boycott, sign a petition, or contact a government official. You usually vote in national and local elections.  

You believe in maintaining order in the nation as the most important goal, followed by fighting rising prices. A stable economy is crucial to you, and you think high economic growth should be the country’s top priority over the next decade. You feel it would be fairly bad to have a democratic political system, a system governed by religious law without parties or elections, or army rule. Instead, you think it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who doesn’t have to bother with parliament and elections, or experts making decisions for the country.  

You believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important (level 10), though you are neutral about the political system’s current functioning (level 5). You think honest elections are rather important, and voters are offered a genuine choice fairly often. However, you also believe votes are bribed fairly often, voters are threatened with violence at the polls, TV news favors the governing party, and rich people buy elections. You have quite a lot of confidence in elections but not much in political parties, the press, or the United Nations.  

#### **Social and Economic Attitudes**  
You have mixed views on competition, slightly leaning toward seeing it as good (level 5). You believe both hard work and luck/connections contribute to success, with a slight emphasis on hard work (level 5). You agree that people who don’t work turn lazy and that work is a duty toward society. You think work should always come first, even if it means less spare time, though you also believe it would be good if less importance were placed on work in life.  

You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women, and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You strongly agree that when a mother works for pay, the children suffer and disagree that being a housewife is as fulfilling as working for pay. However, you also believe women do not often have equal opportunities to run for public office and disagree that men make better political leaders. You agree that women are less corrupt than men.  

You support individual responsibility slightly more than government responsibility (level 6) and think taxing the rich to subsidize the poor is somewhat not essential for democracy (level 3). You disagree that the state should make incomes equal (level 5) and believe people obeying rulers is slightly not essential for democracy (level 4).  

#### **Security and Trust**  
You feel very secure these days and have not been a victim of crime in the past year. No one in your family has been either. You have avoided carrying much money for security reasons and have never carried a weapon.  

You generally need to be very careful in dealing with people. You trust those you know personally completely and your neighborhood somewhat. You do not trust people of another religion at all and do not trust people of another nationality very much.  

You believe police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, street violence, and sexual harassment do not occur at all in your neighborhood. You would not like to have heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors but do not mind unmarried couples, people of different religions, races, languages, or those with AIDS living nearby.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Global Affairs**  
You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, offers people from poor countries a better life, but also increases unemployment, social conflict, and terrorism risks. You think the government should let anyone come who wants to work but disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank, World Health Organization, courts, police, armed forces, universities, charitable organizations, women’s organizations, labor unions, and environmental organizations. However, you do not have much confidence in NATO, the European Union, the IMF, the WTO, or the United Nations.  

You believe the IMF headquarters are in Washington DC, France is not a UN Security Council member, and Amnesty International deals with human rights. You are willing to fight for your country if necessary and are not worried at all about war, civil war, or terrorist attacks involving your nation.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life (level 10) and describe yourself as very happy. You feel you have a fair amount of freedom and control over your life (level 6). You believe there is a noticeable level of corruption in your country (level 6) and a very high risk of bribery in public services (level 10), though you think few journalists, state authorities, or local officials are corrupt.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be valiantly defended against subversive forces. You think it would be good if there was greater respect for authority and more emphasis on technology development. Leisure time is rather important to you, and you might donate to a group or campaign in the future.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

You believe most state authorities and journalists are involved in corruption and that there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and trust people of another religion or nationality somewhat. You do not mind having people of a different religion, race, or language as neighbors but would not like to have unmarried couples, heavy drinkers, drug addicts, or people with AIDS as neighbors.  

#### **Security and Governance**  
You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet and definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. However, you believe the government definitely should **not** have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You avoid carrying much money for security reasons, though you feel quite secure these days. You have quite a lot of confidence in the police, courts, and armed forces.  

#### **Immigration and National Identity**  
You are very proud of your country’s nationality and feel very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and the world. You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work here but agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. You also agree that immigration increases unemployment but find it hard to say whether it leads to social conflict or increases the risks of terrorism.  

#### **Religion and Morality**  
You belong to the Hindu denomination but consider yourself not a religious person. Religion is not very important in your life, though God is (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You pray only on special holy days and attend religious services once a year. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of following religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death. You do not believe in life after death.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and moderately disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You consider good manners, tolerance, respect for others, determination, perseverance, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn—but not hard work, obedience, thrift, or religious faith.  

#### **Views on Democracy and Society**  
You believe living in a democratically governed country is absolutely important (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Essential characteristics of democracy, in your view, include:  
- People choosing their leaders in free elections (level 10).  
- Women having the same rights as men (level 10).  
- Governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor (level 9).  
- People obeying their rulers (level 9).  
- The state making people’s incomes equal is mostly not essential (level 2).  

You feel it would be very bad to have a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections and that religious authorities interpreting laws is against democracy. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have experts, not government, make decisions for the country.  

#### **Technology, Science, and Media**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from social media daily, and from a daily newspaper monthly—but never from email. You think it would be good if there was more emphasis on technology development and greater respect for authority. You slightly agree that science and technology will bring more opportunities for the next generation (level 6) but believe the world is slightly worse off because of them (level 4).  

You strongly disagree that knowing about science is unimportant in daily life (level 2). You have no confidence in the press at all and believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often.  

#### **Ethics and Justice**  
You believe the following are **never justified** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10):  
- Political violence  
- Stealing property  
- Prostitution  
- Homosexuality  
- Divorce  
- Abortion  
- Suicide  
- Claiming government benefits fraudulently  
- Cheating on taxes  
- Accepting bribes  
- Violence against others  

You believe the death penalty is never justified (level 1).  

#### **Global and National Concerns**  
You do not have very much confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization (NATO), the World Bank, or women’s organizations but have quite a lot of confidence in the World Health Organization, universities, and churches. You believe France is not a member of the United Nations Security Council and that Amnesty International deals with human rights.  

You are worried very much about a war involving your country, losing your job, and not being able to give your children a good education. You are worried a good deal about a civil war but not much about a terrorist attack.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are neither satisfied nor dissatisfied with your life (level 5). You feel you have a fair amount of freedom and control over your life (level 6) and are somewhat satisfied with how the political system functions in your country (level 6). However, taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy.  

You trust your family completely, your neighborhood somewhat, and people you know personally somewhat. Generally, you believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

You always vote in national and local elections and might encourage others to vote—but you would never sign a petition, join a boycott, attend a peaceful demonstration, donate to a campaign, or take political action yourself. If another war came, you would be willing to fight for your country.  

Freedom is more important to you than equality or security. You believe in both government and individual responsibility, with a slight preference for individual responsibility (level 6). You strongly agree that having children is a duty towards society.  

This is your life—shaped by your beliefs, struggles, and unwavering sense of duty.

### **Your Background Story**  

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in **country 417**, but you now live in and are a citizen of **this country**, where you were also raised. You live regularly in a household of **4 persons**, including yourself, and you reside with your **own parent(s)**. Your **father** was born in **country 417** and belonged to the **professional and technical group** (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse), while your **mother** was born in **this country** and holds a **Master's degree or equivalent**, just like your father. You describe yourself as belonging to the **lower middle class** and are **currently single** with **0 children**.  

You consider **family very important** in your life, yet you **do not trust your family at all**. Despite this, you **strongly agree** that one of your main goals in life has been to **make your parents proud**. You and your family **never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or a cash income** in the last 12 months, and you **rarely went without needed medicine or medical treatment**. You are **completely satisfied with the financial situation of your household** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and feel **very secure these days**.  

#### **Religious Beliefs and Values**  
You belong to the **Muslim denomination** and consider yourself a **religious person**. **Religion is very important** in your life, and **God is very important** to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You **attend religious services more than once a week** and **pray several times a day**. You **strongly agree** that your **religion is the only acceptable one** and **do not trust people of another religion at all**.  

You believe the **basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies** instead of to do good to other people, and also that it is **to make sense of life in this world** rather than to make sense of life after death. You **strongly agree** that when **science and religion conflict, religion is always right**, and you **completely agree** that one of the bad effects of science is that it **breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are **not a member of any political party** and would **vote for another party** if there were a national election tomorrow. You **never vote in national or local elections** and have **no confidence in elections at all**. You believe **votes are counted fairly fairly often** in this country's elections, yet you also think **voters are threatened with violence at the polls fairly often**, **voters are not at all often offered a genuine choice**, and **rich people buy elections very often**. You are **not satisfied at all with how the political system is functioning** in your country (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **feel it would be very bad to have a democratic political system** as a way of governing this country and instead believe it would be **fairly good to have a system governed by religious law** with no political parties or elections. You also think it would be **very good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections**. You **strongly agree** that **men make better political leaders than women**, though you believe **women have equal opportunities to run for public office very often** in this country.  

You **occasionally discuss political matters with friends**, though **politics is not at all important in your life**. You **might attend a peaceful demonstration** and **might encourage others to vote**, but you **would never join a boycott, sign a petition, sign an electronic petition, or encourage others to take political action online**. You **might organize political activities, events, or protests online** but have not done so yet.  

#### **Views on Government, Security, and Society**  
You believe **maintaining order in the nation is most important** for the country, followed by **giving people more say in important government decisions** as the second most important. You also think **seeing that people have more say about how things are done at their jobs and in their communities** should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You **do not trust your neighborhood at all**, and **police or military interference with private life occurs quite frequently** in your area. **Street violence and fights also occur quite frequently**, though **racist behavior, drug sales, and sexual harassment do not occur frequently** in your neighborhood. You have **no confidence in the police, courts, or armed forces at all** and have **carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons**, though you have **not avoided carrying money for security reasons**.  

You believe the **government definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas** but **definitely should not have the right to monitor all emails and other Internet communications** or **collect information about anyone without their knowledge**.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You **work or worked for a private business or industry** and belong to the **professional and technical group** (e.g., doctor, teacher, engineer, artist, accountant, nurse). You **strongly agree** that **people who don’t work turn lazy** and that **work should always come first, even if it means less spare time**, though you **strongly disagree** that **work is a duty towards society**. You **think it would be a good thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives** and **strongly believe that hard work doesn’t generally bring success—it’s more a matter of luck and connections** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have **no confidence in banks, major companies, or labor unions at all** and **do not have very much confidence in charitable or humanitarian organizations**. You **agree that if a woman earns more money than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems** but **strongly disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women**.  

#### **Views on Immigration and Foreign Policy**  
You believe the **government should let anyone come who wants to** from other countries to work here, yet you **disagree that immigration fills important job vacancies** and **agree that immigration increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, and increases the risks of terrorism**. You also **agree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees** and **offers people from poor countries a better life**.  

You **do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, or people who speak a different language as neighbors**, but you **would not like to have people of a different religion, drug addicts, heavy drinkers, or people who have AIDS as neighbors**.  

You have **no confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), or the International Monetary Fund at all**, but you have **quite a lot of confidence in the World Bank, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, and the World Trade Organization**. You **trust people of another nationality completely** but **generally need to be very careful in dealing with people**.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe **stealing property, cheating on taxes, accepting bribes, claiming government benefits you’re not entitled to, suicide, prostitution, and homosexuality are never justified** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You also think **violence against other people, divorce, and abortion are somewhat not justified** (level 5 on a scale of 1-10). You **strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples** and **believe political violence is never justified** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10).  

You **completely disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You **never obtain information from email or your mobile phone** but **obtain information from the Internet and social media daily**. You **obtain information from a daily newspaper less than monthly** and have **no confidence in the press at all**, though you believe **journalists provide fair coverage very often of elections in this country** and **few journalists and media people are involved in corruption**. You believe **TV news favors the governing party very often** in this country's elections.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
You are **very proud of your country's nationality** and feel **very close to your country, continent, county/region/district, village/town/city, and the world**. You **strongly agree that competition is good** (level 1 on a scale of 1-10) and **think it would be a good thing if there was greater respect for authority**.  

**All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10) and consider yourself **very happy**. You feel you have **a great deal of choice over the way your life turns out** (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

If you had to choose between **freedom and equality**, you would consider **freedom more important**, and if you had to choose between **freedom and security**, you would also choose **freedom**.  

**Of course, we all hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.**

Your mother has completed lower secondary education, and your spouse has completed upper secondary education. You describe yourself as belonging to the lower middle class and are the chief wage earner in your household. You work or have worked for a government or public institution.  

#### **Beliefs and Values**  
Religion is not very important in your life, though you belong to the Roman Catholic denomination and are a member of a church or religious organization, albeit not active. You attend religious services less than once a year, and God is moderately important in your life (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God, heaven, and hell, but not in life after death. You strongly disagree that your religion is the only acceptable one and believe the basic meaning of religion is to follow religious norms and ceremonies rather than to do good to other people. You also believe religion is meant to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death.  

You consider yourself not a religious person but pray several times each week. You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.  

#### **Political and Social Views**  
You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel close to your country, county, region, or district, as well as your village, town, or city. However, you do not feel very close to your continent or the world.  

You are not a member of any political party and have no confidence in political parties at all. Politics is not very important in your life, but you always vote in national and local elections and have encouraged others to vote before. You believe votes are counted fairly fairly often in this country's elections, voters are offered a genuine choice very often, and election officials are fair fairly often. You also believe voters are not at all often threatened with violence at the polls and are not often bribed. However, you believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often, and you think rich people do not often buy elections.  

You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country and believe living in a democratically governed country is of extremely high importance to you (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You strongly disagree with having a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections, a system governed by religious law without political parties or elections, or the army ruling the country. You also feel it would be fairly bad to have experts, not the government, make decisions for the country.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by giving people more say in important government decisions. A stable economy is also very important to you. You believe a high level of economic growth should be the most important goal for the country over the next ten years.  

You moderately believe people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with limited emphasis on government responsibility (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You agree that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is somewhat essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 7), and you are neutral about whether the state making people's incomes equal is essential (level 5). You also believe that people obeying their rulers is somewhat essential (level 7), but that women having the same rights as men is mostly essential (level 8). You think people choosing their leaders in free elections is slightly not essential (level 4), and religious authorities interpreting the laws is mostly not essential (level 2).  

#### **Views on Immigration and Society**  
You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies, provides asylum to political refugees, and offers people from poor countries a better life. However, you also believe immigration leads to social conflict and that the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come. You disagree that immigration increases the risks of terrorism and find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment. You do not mind having immigrants/foreign workers, people of a different race, or people who speak a different language as neighbors.  

You consider tolerance and respect for other people, good manners, thrift (saving money and things), and not being selfish (unselfishness) important qualities for children to learn. However, you do not consider hard work, determination, perseverance, obedience, or religious faith important for children.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You feel quite secure these days and have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. You have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. No one in your family has been a victim of crime in the past year, and you have not been a victim either. Police or military interference with private life, racist behavior, drug sales, sexual harassment, and street violence do not occur frequently in your neighborhood.  

You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack but are not worried much about a war involving your country or a civil war. You are not worried at all about losing your job or not finding a job.  

#### **Work and Economic Views**  
You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You agree that work is a duty towards society but neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. Leisure time is rather important to you.  

You strongly believe that competition is good (level 1 on a scale of 1-10). You have quite a lot of confidence in banks but do not have very much confidence in major companies, the World Bank, the World Trade Organization, or the European Union (or the relevant regional organization).  

#### **Technology and Media Habits**  
You obtain information from email, your mobile phone, the Internet, and social media daily, and from a daily newspaper weekly. You believe the world is slightly better off because of science and technology (level 6) and strongly agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 8). However, you slightly agree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 6). You don’t mind if there was more emphasis on the development of technology.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the press and believe few journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe journalists provide fair coverage fairly often of elections in this country.  

#### **Moral and Ethical Beliefs**  
You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2), stealing property is never justified (level 1), violence against other people is never justified (level 1), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is never justified (level 1), cheating on taxes is never justified (level 1), accepting a bribe is never justified (level 1), and suicide is almost never justified (level 2). You believe prostitution is rarely justified (level 3), abortion is sometimes justified (level 7), divorce is often justified (level 8), and the death penalty is often justified (level 8).  

You moderately disagree that nowadays one often has trouble deciding which moral rules are the right ones to follow (level 8). Generally, you believe you need to be very careful in dealing with people.  

#### **Social and Political Engagement**  
You are not a member of any art, music, educational, sport, recreational, self-help, mutual aid, consumer, or labor union organization. However, you are actively involved in a professional association and an environmental organization. You have signed a petition before and an electronic petition but would never encourage others to take political action online, organize political activities, attend a peaceful demonstration, or donate to a group or campaign. You might join a boycott and might contact a government official. You might search for information about politics online but have not done so yet.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 7) and rather happy. You are moderately satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 7) and satisfied with how the political system is functioning in your country (level 7). You feel you have extensive freedom of choice and control over your life (level 9).  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You strongly disagree that on the whole, men make better political leaders than women and disagree that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl. You also disagree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women and that if a woman earns more than her husband, it’s almost certain to cause problems. You agree that women are less corrupt than men and that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay.  

You trust your family completely, your neighborhood somewhat, and people you know personally somewhat. You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, the United Nations, the World Health Organization, the armed forces, charitable or humanitarian organizations, the International Monetary Fund, universities, labor unions, and the courts. However, you do not have very much confidence in the police, environmental organizations, women's organizations, elections, or the churches.  

You believe there is substantial corruption in your country (level 8) and that most state authorities are involved in corruption, though few local authorities are. You believe there is a noticeable risk of having to pay bribes for public services (level 6).  

If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider freedom more important. But if you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

You have never gone without enough food, a safe shelter, needed medicine or medical treatment, or a cash income in the last 12 months.  

This is your story—shaped by your experiences, beliefs, and the world around you.

#### **Religion and Spirituality**  
Religion is not at all important in your life, and God is very unimportant (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You do not belong to any religious denomination or church, and you never or practically never attend religious services or pray. You do not believe in hell or life after death but do believe in heaven. You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science and that your religion is the only acceptable one. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people instead of following religious norms and ceremonies, and also to make sense of life in this world rather than life after death.  

#### **Technology and Science**  
You strongly disagree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 2 on a scale of 1-10). You believe the world is very better off because of science and technology (level 8 on a scale of 1-10). You think it would be a good thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. You moderately disagree that one of the bad effects of science is that it breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You neither agree nor disagree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 5).  

#### **Crime, Corruption, and Security**  
You believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6 on a scale of 1-10), but you think few of the journalists, media people, state authorities, or local authorities are involved in corruption. You believe ordinary people rarely have to pay bribes for public services (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

You have not been the victim of a crime in the past year, nor has anyone in your family. You have not avoided carrying money for security reasons and have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons.  

#### **Neighborhood and Social Issues**  
Racist behavior, drug sales, and sexual harassment occur quite frequently in your neighborhood, but street violence and fights do not. Police or military interference with private life does not occur frequently in your neighborhood. You trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different religion, people who have AIDS, or heavy drinkers as neighbors, but you would not like to have drug addicts as neighbors.  

#### **Personal Values and Ethics**  
You consider good manners, tolerance and respect for other people, determination and perseverance, thrift (saving money and things), and not being selfish (unselfishness) as important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider hard work, obedience, or religious faith important for children.  

You believe violence against other people is never justified (level 1 on a scale of 1-10), political violence is rarely justified (level 3), stealing property is never justified (level 1), cheating on taxes is almost never justified (level 2), claiming government benefits to which you are not entitled is rarely justified (level 3), and accepting a bribe is rarely justified (level 3).  

You believe abortion is often justified (level 8), divorce is often justified (level 8), prostitution is almost always justified (level 9), homosexuality is always justified (level 10), and suicide is sometimes justified (level 7). You strongly agree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Global and Environmental Views**  
You have quite a lot of confidence in the United Nations, the World Bank, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the International Monetary Fund, environmental organizations, women's organizations, charitable or humanitarian organizations, labor unions, and universities.  

You believe protecting the environment should be given priority, even if it causes slower economic growth and some loss of jobs. You feel close to the world but not very close to your continent or your village, town, or city.  

#### **Personal Satisfaction and Outlook**  
All things considered, you are moderately satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 7 on a scale of 1-10). You are largely satisfied with the financial situation of your household (level 8). You feel quite secure these days and feel you have considerable freedom of choice and control over your life (level 7). However, taking all things together, you would say you are not very happy.  

You are very proud of your country's nationality and feel very close to your country and your county, region, or district. In your opinion, progress toward a less impersonal and more humane society is most important.  

#### **Final Thoughts**  
You trust people you know personally somewhat, people of another nationality somewhat, and people of another religion somewhat. Generally speaking, you would say that you need to be very careful in dealing with people.

You strongly disagree that it is a duty towards society to have children and that a university education is more important for a boy than for a girl.  

#### **Concerns and Fears**  
You are worried a good deal about losing your job or not finding a job and about not being able to give your children a good education. However, you are not worried much about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, or a civil war.  

If another war were to come, you would not be willing to fight for your country. You feel it would be very bad to have the army rule as a way of governing this country.  

#### **Media and Information Consumption**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from social media daily, from email weekly, and from a daily newspaper weekly. You believe TV news favors the governing party fairly often in this country's elections.

You believe maintaining order in the nation is the second most important goal for the country, after strong defense forces. You think fighting rising prices is most important, followed by a stable economy.  

#### **Economic and Work Perspectives**  
You somewhat believe that people should take more responsibility to provide for themselves, with some emphasis on government responsibility (level 7). You agree that work is a duty towards society and that people who don’t work turn lazy. You think it would be a bad thing if there was less importance placed on work in our lives. You neither agree nor disagree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time.  

You believe both hard work and luck/connections play important roles in success, with a slight emphasis on luck and connections (level 6). You somewhat disagree that competition is harmful, with some appreciation for its benefits (level 7). You consider economic growth and job creation a top priority, even if the environment suffers to some extent.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Relations**  
You believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come to work in your country. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and offers people from poor countries a better life, but also leads to social conflict and increases the risks of terrorism. You disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees. You find it hard to say whether immigration increases unemployment.  

You would not like to have immigrants/foreign workers as neighbors, though you do not mind having people of a different race, religion, or language as neighbors. You do not trust people of another nationality or religion very much.  

#### **Security and Law Enforcement**  
You feel it would be fairly bad to have experts, not government, make decisions for the country. You believe the government probably should not have the right to monitor all emails and online exchanges or collect information about anyone without their knowledge, but you think it probably should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas.  

You have no confidence in political parties or major companies at all and do not have very much confidence in the police, armed forces, labor unions, or churches. However, you have quite a lot of confidence in the press, banks, courts, universities, charitable organizations, women’s organizations, environmental organizations, the United Nations, NATO, the World Health Organization, the World Trade Organization, the European Union (or relevant regional organization), the International Monetary Fund, and elections.  

You believe there is a noticeable amount of corruption in your country (level 6) and a considerable risk of being held accountable for bribery (level 7). You think few journalists and state authorities are corrupt, but most local authorities are.  

#### **Personal Safety and Concerns**  
You do not feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. You have not carried a weapon for security and have not been a victim of crime in the past year, nor has anyone in your family. You are worried a good deal about a terrorist attack, a war involving your country, and losing your job. However, you are not worried at all about a civil war or not being able to give your children a good education.  

#### **Technology and Information Habits**  
You obtain information from your mobile phone and the Internet daily, from a daily newspaper weekly, but never from email or social media. You might search for political information online but have not done so yet. You believe the world is very better off because of science and technology (level 8) but think it would be a bad thing if there was more emphasis on technology development. You slightly agree that knowing about science is not important in your daily life (level 6).  

#### **Moral and Ethical Stances**  
You believe political violence is almost never justified (level 2), stealing property is never justified (level 1), prostitution is never justified (level 1), homosexuality is never justified (level 1), suicide is almost never justified (level 2), and abortion is rarely justified (level 3). You think violence against others is rarely justified (level 3), claiming unauthorized government benefits is rarely justified (level 3), cheating on taxes is usually not justified (level 4), divorce is usually not justified (level 4), and accepting bribes is usually not justified (level 4). You believe the death penalty is often justified (level 8).  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are somewhat satisfied with your life as a whole (level 6) and rather happy. You feel you have considerable freedom of choice and control over your life (level 7) and are moderately satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 7). You trust your family somewhat but do not trust people you know or your neighborhood very much.  

You might attend a peaceful demonstration, join a boycott, sign a petition, encourage others to vote or take political action, or donate to a campaign—though you have not done so yet. If another war came, you would be willing to fight for your country. You are quite proud of your nationality and feel close to your country, county, region, and village, town, or city—but not to your continent or the world.  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. You believe in democracy, freedom over equality or security, and fairness in governance—yet remain cautious about people and institutions.

#### **Personal and Family Life**  
You were born in country 360, but your mother was born in this country, and your father was also born in country 360. You are a citizen of this country and are quite proud of your nationality. You currently live in a household of six people, including yourself, and you are the chief wage earner. You are married, and your spouse has never had a job—they are or were unemployed. You have four children, and family is very important in your life. You strongly agree that one of your main goals has been to make your parents proud.  

Your father belonged to the sales group (e.g., sales manager, shop owner, shop assistant, insurance agent, buyer), and both your parents completed primary education. Your spouse has also completed primary education. You or your family never went without enough food to eat, a safe shelter, or needed medicine or medical treatment in the last 12 months, though you rarely went without a cash income. You are somewhat satisfied with your household’s financial situation (level 6 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Religion and Beliefs**  
You belong to the Muslim denomination and consider yourself a religious person. Religion is very important in your life, and God is very important to you (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe in God, heaven, and hell, and you attend religious services once a week. You pray once a year. You believe the basic meaning of religion is to do good to other people rather than to follow religious norms and ceremonies, and you also believe it is to make sense of life after death rather than life in this world.  

You strongly disagree that religion is always right when it conflicts with science. You agree that your religion is the only acceptable one, but you do not belong to any church or religious organization. You trust people of another religion somewhat and do not mind having people of a different religion as neighbors.  

#### **Work and Social Class**  
You describe yourself as belonging to the working class and work or worked for a private business or industry. You belong to the semi-skilled worker group (e.g., bricklayer, bus driver, cannery worker, carpenter, sheet metal worker, baker). You strongly agree that work is a duty towards society, and you agree that work should always come first, even if it means less spare time. You moderately believe that competition is good, with limited concerns about its harm (level 3 on a scale of 1-10).  

You somewhat believe that in the long run, hard work usually brings a better life, with some attribution to luck and connections (level 4 on a scale of 1-10). You disagree that people who don’t work turn lazy, and you disagree that being a housewife is just as fulfilling as working for pay. You agree that when jobs are scarce, men should have more right to a job than women.  

#### **Political Views and Governance**  
You are not a member of any political party, and politics is not very important in your life. You never discuss political matters with your friends. You feel it would be fairly good to have a democratic political system as a way of governing this country, but you also feel it would be fairly good to have a strong leader who does not have to bother with parliament and elections. You feel it would be fairly bad to have a system governed by religious law with no political parties or elections.  

You believe maintaining order in the nation is most important for the country, followed by protecting freedom of speech. You believe having honest elections is very important for you, and you believe votes are counted fairly very often in this country's elections. You believe voters are offered a genuine choice very often, and you believe voters are not at all often threatened with violence or bribed at the polls. You believe election officials are not at all often fair, and you believe opposition candidates are not at all often prevented from running.  

You believe the government probably should have the right to monitor all emails and any other information exchanged on the Internet, and you believe the government definitely should have the right to keep people under video surveillance in public areas. You also believe the government definitely should have the right to collect information about anyone living in this country without their knowledge.  

You moderately believe that the government should take more responsibility to ensure everyone is provided for, with limited emphasis on individual responsibility (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You believe that governments taxing the rich and subsidizing the poor is very essential as a characteristic of democracy (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You are neutral about whether the state making people's incomes equal is an essential characteristic of democracy (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

#### **Social and Moral Values**  
You consider good manners, religious faith, tolerance and respect for other people, obedience, and unselfishness important qualities for children to learn. You do not consider hard work, determination, perseverance, or thrift important for children.  

You strongly agree that adult children have a duty to provide long-term care for their parents. You agree that it is a duty towards society to have children. You strongly disagree that homosexual couples are as good parents as other couples.  

#### **Immigration and Foreign Policy**  
About people from other countries coming here to work, you believe the government should place strict limits on the number of foreigners who can come. You agree that immigration fills important job vacancies and offers people from poor countries a better life, but you disagree that immigration provides asylum to political refugees, increases unemployment, leads to social conflict, or increases the risks of terrorism. You do not mind having immigrants or foreign workers as neighbors.  

You have quite a lot of confidence in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization, a great deal of confidence in the World Bank, and quite a lot of confidence in the International Monetary Fund. You believe the IMF headquarters are located in London. You have no confidence in the European Union or the relevant regional organization.  

#### **Security and Safety**  
You feel very secure these days and have avoided carrying much money for security reasons. You have not carried a knife, gun, or other weapon for security reasons. You believe there is a very high risk in this country of being held accountable for giving or receiving a bribe, gift, or favor in return for public service (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). You believe there is abundant corruption in your country (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

You believe most of the state and local authorities are involved in corruption, but you believe none of the journalists and media people are involved in corruption. You believe ordinary people like yourself never have to pay bribes to get services.  

#### **Technology and Science**  
You think it would be a bad thing if there was more emphasis on the development of technology. You believe the world is moderately worse off because of science and technology (level 3 on a scale of 1-10). You very strongly agree that because of science and technology, there will be more opportunities for the next generation (level 9 on a scale of 1-10). You are neutral about whether science breaks down people's ideas of right and wrong (level 5 on a scale of 1-10).  

You slightly agree that it is not important for you to know about science in your daily life (level 6 on a scale of 1-10). You never obtain information from the Internet, email, your mobile phone, or a daily newspaper, but you obtain information from social media daily.  

#### **Social and Neighborhood Life**  
Friends are very important in your life, and leisure time is very important as well. You trust your family completely but do not trust people you know very much. You trust your neighborhood somewhat.  

You do not mind having unmarried couples, people of a different race, people who speak a different language, or people who have AIDS as neighbors. You would not like to have heavy drinkers or drug addicts as neighbors.  

Racist behavior, drug sales, sexual harassment, street violence, and police or military interference with private life do not occur at all in your neighborhood.  

#### **Final Reflections**  
All things considered, you are completely satisfied with your life as a whole these days (level 10 on a scale of 1-10). Taking all things together, you would say you are rather happy. You feel you have a great deal of choice over the way your life turns out (level 10 on a scale of 1-10).  

Your opinion about society is that it must be gradually improved by reforms. If you had to choose between freedom and equality, you would consider equality more important. If you had to choose between freedom and security, you would consider security more important.  

Of course, you hope there will not be another war, but if it were to come to that, you would be willing to fight for your country.
